urn:contentItem:606T-WSK1-DYTM-92WJ-00000-00TECH TRAFFICKING: HOW THE INTERNET HAS TRANSFORMED SEX TRAFFICKING.2020-07-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisPg. 338TECH TRAFFICKING: HOW THE INTERNET HAS TRANSFORMED SEX TRAFFICKING.Prylinski, Kirsten M.

I. Introduction

Human trafficking is the largest manifestation of slavery today, generating billions of dollars each year in illegal proceeds. (1) When first confronted with stories from the news or facts about human trafficking, it seems like there is no way that it could be true. (2) How is it possible that women and children are being bought and sold online without a trace? (3) Nevertheless, the reality is that human trafficking, and more specifically sex trafficking, is happening at rates that both the government and the public cannot keep up with. (4)

Human trafficking is a hidden crime. (5) It often includes forced labor, domestic servitude, forced marriages, and most commonly, commercial sex. (6) Globally, the most common form of human trafficking is sex trafficking. (7) Sex trafficking encompasses activities related to prostitution, commercial sexual activities, sex tourism, and pornography. (8) it undermines core human rights, as well as destroys and threatens the safety of communities. (9) With the aid of new technologies, women and children are being bought and sold online without a trace. (10) Today, these new technologies continue to outpace the law, taking human trafficking into the deepest corners of the internet, undetectable by law enforcement. (11)

In 2000, Congress discovered that 700,000 persons annually, primarily women and children, were being trafficked within or across international borders. (12) in 2018, it was estimated that over 100,000 human trafficking victims had been identified globally, thousands of which came in and out of the united states. (13) With the rise of the internet, the market for sex trafficking went global, with the internet becoming the mecca. (14) specifically, many victims meet their traffickers over the internet by being coerced with promises of a better life. (15) Nevertheless, the relationship will quickly turn toxic with the trafficker becoming controlling and abusive. (16) In 2016, the National center for Missing and Exploited children reported an 846% increase from 2010 to 2015 in reports of suspected child trafficking. (17) This increase was found to be directly correlated to the increase in the use of the internet in selling children for sex. (18)

The advancement of technology is fueling sex trafficking, and legislation is not moving fast enough. (19) In 2017, Congress passed the Allow states and Victims to Fight online sex Trafficking Act ("FOSTA"). (20) This Act was passed with the purpose of amending the Communications Decency Act of 1934, and no longer granting immunity to internet service providers ("ISPs"), whose websites "knowingly" publish illegal sex trafficking content. (21) in hindsight, FosTA is a progressive enactment to help stop online sex trafficking, but this Act has unintended consequences. (22) For instance, instead of promoting companies to better ensure there is no illegal sex trafficking content being published on their websites, these companies are instead taking necessary steps to avoid liability for "knowingly" facilitating online sex trafficking. (23) Therefore, Congress needs to keep working to not only put in place the proper preventative measures, but to also catch up or get ahead in the technological race that is currently being won by sex traffickers.

II. History

A. The Rise of Technology in Sex Trafficking

Before the internet became mainstream, newsgroups and newspapers were the main media outlet for sex trafficking advertisements. (24) However, with the rise of technology and the internet, there has been a radical transformation in the landscape of sex trafficking. (25) With the use of the internet, sex trafficking can be conducted online. (26) By the mid 1990s, women and children were being marketed worldwide. (27) in 1994, the first prostitution website was launched. (28) This website enabled perpetrators to market women for services around the world. (29) Shortly after the establishment of prostitution websites, the "World Sex Guide" launched online. (30) Here, men from around the world could leave reviews on women based on how easily they were able to coerce them in to "painful, risky, or humiliating" sex acts. (31) This later led to the creation of video chatting where with a little less than the click of a mouse, perpetrators had access to victims. (32)

The urgency to end sex trafficking came to the world's attention in 1999, due to the establishment of online rape camps. (33) These rape camps were live video chats, where viewers were given the capability to request acts of sexual assault and torture that were then carried out on the victim. (34) With new video chat technology, perpetrators were able to record and re-watch the once live sex shows. (35) This technology allowed video recordings to be used on websites as a way for traffickers to market women and children. (36) These new technological capabilities captured the attention of the legislature and compelled them to act. (37)

B. The Communications Decency Act of 1996

In 1996, the Communications Decency Act ("CDA") was enacted by Congress as a way to regulate the distribution of obscene or indecent material on the internet. (38) The Act states that "no provider or user of an [ISP] shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider." (39) Further, Section 230 of the CDA protects websites based on a "good faith" effort to report or block material that the provider considers to be "obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, excessively violent, harassing or otherwise objectionable, whether or not such material is constitutionally protected." (40) Essentially, Section 230 of the CDA is providing broad immunity to ISPs. (41) Nonetheless, the Ninth Circuit held that if a website plays any part in editing content to make it more acceptable for posting purposes, then they can risk losing their immunity under the CDA. (42) With Section 230 of the CDA in play, the courts have struggled to assign liability to those truly responsible for the buying and selling of sex online. (43)

C. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000

In 2000, the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act ("TVPA of 2000") was enacted by Congress. (44) This Act served as the first federal law to protect victims and prosecute traffickers. (45) Moreover, along with this bill came the Interagency Task Force to monitor and combat trafficking. (46) The Task Force was established with three objectives: (1) to collect data and research on domestic and international trafficking; (2) to evaluate the progress that the United States and other countries were taking to prevent, protect, and prosecute human trafficking; and (3) to cooperate with other nations as an effort to end trafficking globally. (47)

The TVPA of 2000 was not only meant to help combat human trafficking, but to also give aid to women who were prone to becoming victims of sex trafficking. (48) The TVPA of 2000 accomplished this goal through establishing various prevention programs with the objective of deterring prostitution. (49) Further, the Bill established the "T Visa," which allowed non-residents who were victims of sex trafficking to become temporary residents of the United States, and be eligible for the Witness Protection Program. (50) Additionally, the TVPA of 2000 made all forms of human trafficking a federal crime. (51) Not only did the United States seek to end trafficking, but they sought to aid and support those who had been victimized by such acts. (52)

D. Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003

In 2003, the Bush Administration enacted the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act ("TVPRA of 2003") to further combat human trafficking. (53) This reauthorization added to the TVPA of 2000 by authorizing over $200 million to combat human trafficking and renewing the United States' commitment to ending human trafficking. (54) The TVPRA of 2003 gave victims even more access to aid, and allowed them to bring civil suits against traffickers in order to recover punitive damages. (55)

E. Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2013

By 2012, President Barack obama stated that human trafficking was "the most pressing human rights issue of our time." (56) This stark realization warranted the enactment of the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2013 ("TVPRA of 2013"). (57) Different from the previous Victim Protection Acts, this Act focused on the rapid growth of technology and how it affected human trafficking. (58) The goal behind the 2013 Reauthorization was to initiate the use of technology to combat trafficking online. (59) Law enforcement would use electronic surveillance, and data from cellphones or computers to monitor and find suspected perpetrators involved in human trafficking. (60)

Additionally, soon after the passing of the 2013 Reauthorization Act, ISP tech companies in the private sector got involved in the fight against human trafficking. (61) ISP tech companies were forming company-wide initiatives to detect traffickers and supply victims with resources to get help. (62) Nonetheless, ISPs operate as neutral forum websites where users can post their own content to the site. (63) Though some websites are enacting protocols to stop trafficking, other websites are enabling buyers and sellers of sex to maintain their anonymity, while remaining free of legal consequences. (64)

F. The Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act

On March 21, 2018, Congress passed into law the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act ("FOSTA"). (65) This Act clarified that the CDA "was never intended to provide legal protection to websites that unlawfully promote and facilitate prostitution and websites that facilitate traffickers in the sale of unlawful sex." (66) The FOSTA states that to "participate" means to "knowingly assist, support, or facilitate" sex trafficking. (67) With the passing of the FOSTA, ISPS could no longer escape civil and criminal liability relating to the exploitation of children or sex trafficking. (68)

G. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2018

In an effort to further combat human trafficking, on January 8, 2019, President Trump signed the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2018 ("TVPRA of 2018"). (69) This Act reauthorized existing efforts that have been in place since the Act's creation in 2000, as well as launched new initiatives. (70) This legislation seeks to accomplish three major goals: (1) stronger law enforcement; (2) government and corporate accountability; and (3) prevention efforts. (71) Specifically, this Act will give prosecutors the crucial resources necessary to efficiently and effectively prosecute human trafficking related crimes. (72) The law will also develop victim screening protocols as well as foster coordination between federal, state and local law enforcement in order to bring multi-jurisdictional cases. (73) Further, corporate and governmental entities will now be held accountable for being involved, either directly or indirectly, for participating in activities that support human trafficking. (74) Together, the government and corporations can work to ensure that business coming in, or occurring in the United States, is not a product of human trafficking. (75) Finally, this Act implements funding for educational programs that teach children the signs of human trafficking. (76) These educational efforts provide a way to prevent human trafficking before it starts as opposed to merely reacting. (77) These three major incentives will function to detect human trafficking in both the United States and abroad. (78)

III. Facts

The United States has made continuous efforts to pass evolving legislation that combats the growth of human trafficking, namely sex trafficking. (79) While the executive branch acknowledges the grave threat that trafficking poses on human rights, the judiciary struggles on where to assign the blame. (80) Nonetheless, the legislature continues to try to franticly pass laws that will stop crimes online without violating constitutional rights. (81) Much of the human trafficking legislation passed through Congress has focused on the resources provided for victims, but has failed to put significant preventative measures in place. (82) Simply put, new legislation is not accounting for the technological advancements of society. (83)

A. Technology is Outpacing the Law

Technology is outpacing the law, and traffickers are using this to their advantage. (84) Many traffickers use technology to recruit, control, and exploit victims. (85) With the use of technology, traffickers are able to meet, keep, and sell their victims. (86) Typically, ISP websites are a main source for human trafficking. (87) Traffickers post illegal advertisements for commercial sex with links connecting buyers and sellers to various goods. (88) Further, these practices of selling children have remained hidden online, and gone undetected by law enforcement. (89) in the era of technology, traffickers continue to find loopholes that allow them remain undercover. (90)

Nevertheless, iSP websites were exploited to the public during the Backpage.com ("Backpage") investigation. (91) Backpage, an ISP website, became the primary location for the sale of sex online. (92) On Backpage, traffickers would routinely post ads in the adult section of the site. (93) Here, traffickers were able to conduct their illegal activities, while Backpage would profit. (94) Though Backpage was created in 2004, it was able to remain undetected in its part in editing advertisements until 2016. (95) During their investigation, the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations concluded that Backpage had introduced an "ad hoc" policy, where moderators would manually remove words, phrases, or images that indicated any illegal transactions before publishing ads to their site. (96) This policy allowed Backpage to hide the illegality of the advertisements, while maintaining the purpose--a commercial sex transaction. (97) Although there were protections for victims of sex trafficking through the prior Acts, ISPs, such as Backpage, were able to escape responsibility for sex trafficking under the CDA. (98)

B. Legislation is Reacting, but Not Doing

The FOSTA is at odds with the CDA and the protection it provides to ISP websites. (99) The final draft of the FOSTA left technology companies unclear on what would constitute as "knowing facilitation." (100) When the FOSTA was in the beginning stages of legislation, tech companies such as Google, who pride themselves on being allies against sex-trafficking, supported the new law. (101) However, the unclear language of the bill raised concerns that the "Good Samaritan" rules would no longer apply, thus actually crippling the fight against sex trafficking. (102) For example, if a tech company would be held liable for "knowing" of sex trafficking on their site, even though trying to remove it, they may simply stop looking for it as a means to shield themselves from liability. (103)

Those who argue against the bill suggest that it should have been written more comprehensively. (104) Critics argue that the bill should have included other forms of illegal activity, as well as be able to grant immunity to sites that can show they reasonably responded to unlawful activity on their site. (105) While big tech companies, such as Google and Facebook, can handle the finances of a lawsuit under this new legislation, they have banded together with small ISP tech companies in advocating against the FOSTA. (106)

Alternatively, tech companies could be partly to blame for the necessity of the FOSTA because of industry-wide inattentiveness. (107) For some brief amount of time it is possible that websites, such as Backpage, were unaware of child sex trafficking occurring on their site. (108) Undoubtedly, because of the magnitude of illegal activity taking place on their site, it became clear that Backpage was knowingly facilitating sex trafficking. (109) With this, ISP websites should bear some liability for not monitoring their site closely enough to recognize illegal activity taking place. (110)

C. The Risks of Censoring Internet Service Provider Websites

Advocates for free speech have cautioned that censoring ISPs could put sex trafficking victims in danger. (111) A number of free speech organizations raised concerns about the regulation of speech for consensual sex online. (112) However, these arguments go head-to-head with a number of Supreme Court decisions on illegal speech. (113) The Supreme Court has issued decisions that specifically relate to child pornography and the protection of children from sexual abuse. (114) But, in order for the government to restrict a constitutionally granted right, there must be a compelling governmental interest. (115) It is clear that the government's interest in protecting children from sexual abuse substantially outweighs some forms of free speech online. (116) The government's desire to protect these children thwarts tech companies' arguments that censoring their online activities would be a violation of free speech. (117)

IV. Analysis

A. The FOSTA Needs to be Updated

The FOSTA is the most significant piece of internet legislation in the last two decades. (118) Nevertheless, its use of ambiguous language is having devastating consequences. (119) The language of the FOSTA calls for civil or criminal liability against sites that "knowingly" allow sex trafficking to occur on their websites, which is practically forcing sites to turn a blind eye to illegal activity on their sites. (120) In hindsight, the FOSTA is a major step in the right direction, but at a second glance, the new legislation has the ability to lead to a larger human trafficking crisis. (121)

Before the FOSTA, tech companies could put forth a "good-faith" effort by working with law enforcement to combat sex trafficking online. (122) However, this new legislation demands that every byte of content is monitored with small margin for error. (123) Thus, countless lawsuits are being filed for failure to get illegal content off of a website. (124) Big tech companies, such as Google, Microsoft, or Facebook, have the resources to monitor content and defend themselves against litigation. (125) However, smaller tech companies do not have the same capabilities. (126) This has led to small tech companies no longer seeking out illegal activity on their sites. (127) Instead of the FOSTA putting an end to online sex trafficking, it has put the full responsibility of finding and stopping illegal content on the internet onto ISPs. (128) The FOSTA has placed immense pressure on tech companies, and may not actually end online sex trafficking. (129)

Further, the FOSTA remains unclear through its ambiguous language on the expectations that are now in place for iSP websites. (130) Alternatively, if this new legislation is meant to incentivize tech companies to vigilantly find and stop the illegal activity on their sites, then sex trafficking is just one of the countless number of crimes ISPs could potentially be liable for reporting. (131) This could leave Facebook on the hook for drug transactions that are initiated through a status update. (132) It could also lead Google to censor content for legal activity in one state that is a crime in another state. (133) The law remains unclear about whether or not sex trafficking is the only crime sites should be looking for. (134)

With this in mind, one thing remains clear after considering opinions on the FOSTA. (135) The passing of the FOSTA is long overdue as it pertains to ending sex trafficking online, especially for children. (136) But, there needs to be a much brighter line drawn for ISP websites that identify what "knowingly facilitating" illegal activity on their sites means. (137) The legislation needs to specifically state what activities ISP websites need to be looking for. (138) Clarity is essential for law enforcement to comprehend the circumstances surrounding the illegal activity found on a given website. (139) Furthermore, in order for the judiciary to achieve justice, the rules must be clear so they can investigate and determine if the site was in fact "knowingly facilitating" illegal activity. (140)

B. The Significance of the TVPA of 2018

While disputes continue about the FOSTA, the signing of the TVPA of 2018 has been well received. (141) President Trump stands firm on his commitment to ending sex trafficking, and has made it clear that the United States will not tolerate human trafficking, including sex trafficking. (142) Throughout history, legislation has merely reacted to sex trafficking. (143) Though the United States has implemented programs to help the victims of trafficking, as well as give funding to initiatives to combat trafficking, the crime continues to increase. (144) The rehabilitation of victims is imperative, but it is more imperative that sex trafficking be stopped before it even starts. (145)

Fortunately, the signing of the TVPA of 2018 implements major resources for prosecutors so they can efficiently investigate and effectively prosecute traffickers. (146) This new legislation pours resources into educating every person, including children, to the signs of sex trafficking. (147) Educating children about the signs of sex trafficking, especially online, has yet to be seen in prior legislation, and not knowing what to be aware of put children at a heightened risk of being trafficked. (148) Further, trafficked victims are normally people who are already at risk, thus educating people on the signs of sex trafficking is critical. (149) These crucial steps taken are imperative if the United States is going to stay ahead of sex trafficking, instead of continuing to be outpaced by technology.

C. The Needfor Collaboration Between Tech Companies and the Government

Sex trafficking is a global problem that is going to require the collaboration of technology companies and the government if they want to be successful at ending it. (150) Perpetrators of sex trafficking have become experts in social media, fake profiles, and the hidden sex markets of the internet. (151) They use technology to their advantage to outsmart and remain hidden from law enforcement. (152) Nevertheless, with the help of tech companies, law enforcement may be able to more easily detect and remove perpetrators from online. (153) While tech companies right now may just be avoiding liability, they can do so much more than that. (154) They can work with law enforcement to understand how technology is used to traffic, and then provide viable solutions. (155) Sex trafficking cannot be stopped without the help and effort of everyone involved--whether by choice or not. (156) Further, with sex trafficking taking on such a technology based platform, it is quickly pushing its way to the headlines of the news, and Americans are becoming acutely aware of the growing dangers that sex trafficking poses. (157) Now, all eyes are on both tech companies and the government to see how these two forces will work to end sex trafficking. (158) The solutions are there, but it will take the collaboration from everyone to find and execute them. (159)

V. Conclusion

Sex trafficking is happening in every neighborhood, every city and every country around the world, and the internet is only accelerating the market. The advancement of technology has allowed traffickers to take their business to the darkest corners of the internet and remain largely undetectable. Though past legislation has missed the mark or caused push-back, it was still progress. Nevertheless, the newest Trafficking Victims Reauthorization Act signed by President Trump is paving the way for tackling sex trafficking head on. As sex trafficking emerges from the hidden corners of the internet, it is imperative that the United States stays on the cutting edge of the fight against sex trafficking.

Id. Id.

"The evidentiary record makes clear that Backpage's executive knew their websites facilitated illegal activity, including child sex trafficking." Id. 16-17.

(Apr. 1, 2019), archived at https://perma.cc/P4RV-LDMW (summarizing the opinion of now retired Justice Anthony Kennedy that social media is one of the greatest battlegrounds for free expression both nationally and globally).

First, there is an interest in protecting the physical and psychological well-being of a child. Id. at 756-57. Second, it is a supported fact that the distribution of child pornography links to the sexual abuse of children. Id. at 759. Third, marketing child pornography provides an economic incentive for the production of such materials. Id. at 761. Fourth, the minimal "value of permitting live performance and photographic reproductions of children engaged in lewd sexual conduct" is insignificant. Id. at 762. Ohio, 495 U.S. 103, 109-10 (1990) (upholding that the mere possession of child pornography as unlawful). B15Tech, Trump face off over pro-coal plansSilicon Valley is demanding more clean energy than some utilities are ready to offerEmma Ockerman Bloomberg

Selling custom nose rings, crocheted bunnies and hand-carved Santas is energy-intensive stuff.

Just ask Etsy Inc., the go-to marketplace for crafts that doubled its electricity use in two years to feed power-sucking data centres that keep the $2.8-billion-a-year (U.S.) business running. It's one of the many technology giants, including Amazon.com and Alphabet's Google, demanding cheaper - and cleaner - electricity as their data demands grow. This hunger for power has set Silicon Valley on a collision course with the Trump administration, which is working up a plan to keep coal plants afloat by raising electricity prices.

As a rare source of demand growth, these tech firms have become formidable advocates for clean energy. They have contracted enough renewable energy to displace at least 12 coal generators, and some are paying millions to sever ties with utilities to find their own supply.

Big Tech is no longer "afraid to throw around their weight or their ability to influence - some might say bully - their local utility or local governments in what they want to get," said Lucas Beran, a senior research analyst on IHS Markit's data centre and cloud team.

It's easy to see why the companies have become such advocates. Power used by all the nation's data centres is set to climb 4 per cent from 2014 to 2020, according to an Energy Department report.

Server farms now draw enough electricity to light up Las Vegas and the rest of Nevada, twice over. Etsy alone used 10,679 megawatt-hours last year, enough to supply 1,000 homes.

While coal still accounts for about a third of U.S. electricity, it is losing ground to cheaper natural gas, wind and solar.

Hundreds of mines have shut in recent years and U.S. President Donald Trump campaigned on a pledge to revive them. His administration is now calling on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to enact a plan that would subsidize coal-fired power plants.

In a letter last month, Etsy called on regulators to reject Trump's plan, which it described as a barrier to "making creative entrepreneurship a path to economic security."

Separately, a group that includes Amazon and Microsoft Corp. said the administration is overlooking the potential of renewable power, grid technology and energy storage, warning that the proposal would create "burdensome out-of-market costs on consumers like our companies."

Their push for clean power extends well beyond Washington.

Alphabet has called on utilities to create "buy-as-you-go" renewable energy programs. The demands of modern electricity consumers have outgrown the standard utility business model designed "for a bygone era," it said in a white paper last year.

The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., runs the world's largest online search engine. It has signed contracts to buy 2.6 gigawatts of renewable energy that it said will lead to $3.5 billion of investments.

The fight to transform power supplies is just the latest instance of technology companies flexing their political muscle and green image. Earlier this year, the industry opposed Trump's decision to remove the U.S. from the international Paris climate accord. Many, including Google, Microsoft and Facebook pledged to continue the battle against global warming.

Meanwhile, building solar and wind farms is now less expensive than keeping coal generators online in parts of the U.S., and solar power is set to become the world's cheapest source of electricity. Renewables account for about 15 per cent of the U.S. power mix, compared with almost nothing two decades ago.

Utilities aren't opposed to investing in renewable power. But technology companies are demanding supplies in quantities that could disrupt the reliability of transmission systems, said Matt Mooren, an energy analyst with PA Consulting Group.

Electricity is notoriously hard to store, so for the most part, it must be used instantaneously. Solar and wind farms don't work when the sun isn't shining and wind isn't blowing. That creates a juggling act for utilities that must maintain a steady flow of power to customers.

Industry consultant Lazard estimates a grid can handle about 30 per cent of its power coming from renewables. Beyond that, utilities need backup systems such as batteries or conventional power plants.

Even so, the technology industry won't let up on its demands, said Mark Mills, a senior fellow at the free-market think tank Manhattan Institute who authored the 2013 study "The Cloud Begins With Coal."

Switch Inc., a Las Vegas data-centre provider, agreed to pay $27 million last year to leave its Nevada utility in a bet that the company could find cheaper renewable energy elsewhere. Microsoft paid almost $24 million to bypass a Washington utility and find power on its own.

In West Virginia, the heart of America's Coal Country, potter Joy Bridy makes everything from mugs to sauerkraut crocks that she sells on Etsy. Her operation is powered by solar panels that Etsy helped her get.

Despite her state's deep roots in coal, she backs the company's fight for more renewable energy.

"That's the way the ball's rolling," Bridy said. "The sooner we all get with the program, the better it will be."

urn:contentItem:5WJK-K791-JCB9-40W3-00000-00Tech turns to K Street in antitrust fight2019-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisPg. 14Tech turns to K Street in antitrust fightBy Alex Gangitano

New scrutiny from regulators and Congress over the tech industry's antitrust issues is putting Silicon Valley's K Street support to the test.

Tech giants such as Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple have been beefing up their lobbying teams, bringing in both in-house talent and outside firms.

The threat of an antitrust crackdown on tech companies is sparking a new flurry of activity. For lobbying firms there is a rush to snap up potentially lucrative contracts, but also pressure to deliver as the tech industry faces one of its toughest battles.

"Antitrust investigations are fact-intensive by their nature and these are complicated, fast-moving markets. It's no surprise that the big tech companies are staffing up with people to help answer inquiries from antitrust enforcers," said Nuala O'Connor, president and CEO of the Center for Democracy and Technology.

Tech companies are no strangers to K Street and have been boosting their lobbying spending in recent years, attracting some of the top talent in Washington. Tech companies have faced a host of legislative and regulatory questions in recent years, including over data privacy scandals, workforce diversity, encryption, net neutrality and trade. But for Silicon Valley, the prospect of federal regulators looking into their market power could shake up their business models and drastically change their companies.

Both the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and Department of Justice (DOJ) are weighing probes into the industry's biggest players, and Congress has opened its own investigation into whether to rewrite the nation's antitrust laws for the new economy.

The increased scrutiny also comes with the industry finding few allies in Washington.

Critics, including President Trump and 2020 contender Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), have even floated breaking up the companies to level the playing field.

Enlisting help from the influence world will be critical to helping fight off that threat, K Street watchers told The Hill.

"Washington likes to control anything that's important, and today that includes online platforms," Carl Szabo, vice president and general counsel at NetChoice, a trade association of e-commerce businesses, said.

"Silicon Valley has woken up to this reality and is hiring accordingly. This is the normal path of any business as it grows."

The antitrust fight could be a gold mine for lobbying firms as tech companies beef up their Washington presence. But there are also high stakes for those firms and executives at trade associations, who must now deliver and help the industry fight off the threat.

That pressure is being highlighted by Google, a unit of Alphabet Inc., which is undertaking a major overhaul of its government affairs operation. The company has fired outside firms, shaken up its policy team and seen the departure of two senior officials in Washington as it rethinks its lobbying efforts, The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday.

Google spent more than $21.7 million on lobbying expenditures in 2018. So far in 2019, it has spent $3.5 million amid the reshuffle. The six outside firms Google dropped accounted for $20 million of its annual lobbying bill, according to the Journal.

Like Google, other tech companies have also been throwing large sums at K Street.

Amazon has spent more than Google so far this year, with just under $4 million on lobbying. That figure puts it on pace to surpass the $14.4 million it spent on lobbying in 2018.

Amazon's ramped-up K Street operation comes as it also makes plans to place its second headquarters in the Washington, D.C., area. The company has increased its lobbying expenditures every year since 2008, when it spent $1.3 million on lobbying.

McGuireWoods LLP is its top law and lobbying firm, receiving $90,000 from the online retailer so far this year. Its second top lobbying firm is Ballard Partners, which is the firm of Brian Ballard, a top fundraiser for Trump.

Facebook is third among the industry's four giants this year, with $3.4 million spent on lobbying expenditures so far in 2019 and on target to at least match the $12.6 million spent for 2018. Lobbying and law firm Steptoe & Johnson has a $130,000 contract with the company.

Of the big four tech players, Apple has the smallest lobbying footprint. It has spent more than $1.9 million on lobbying so far in 2019 and has four firms on retainer. In 2018, it spent more than $6.6 million, down from the more than $7.1 million spent in 2017.

The companies have also snapped up a number of prominent lobbyists, including at Facebook, which hired Catlin O'Neill, who was chief of staff to Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) before leaving in 2013.

The tech industry's lobbying forces will have to move quickly.

According to reports, the DOJ and FTC have reportedly reached an agreement on how to divide up oversight, with the DOJ focusing on Apple and Google and the FTC setting its sights on Facebook and Amazon.

And on Tuesday, the House Judiciary Committee held the first hearing in its antitrust probe, hearing from publishers who say that companies like Google and Facebook have cornered the market in digital ads.

"It is incumbent on Congress to understand the sources of this problem and address it urgently," said House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.). "Congress also has a constitutional duty to ensure markets are structured in a way that is compatible with our democratic values."

urn:contentItem:5X09-9HG1-DYTY-C1KY-00000-00Tech tycoon Benioff calls in big-hitters to join his band;Technology Intelligence ; Gavin Patterson, the former BT chief, is the latest high-profile appointment at Salesforce, report Robin Pagnamenta and James Titcomb in San Francisco2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 5Tech tycoon Benioff calls in big-hitters to join his bandTechnology Intelligence ; Gavin Patterson, the former BT chief, is the latest high-profile appointment at Salesforce, report Robin Pagnamenta and James Titcomb in San FranciscoJames Titcomb

It was January 2017 and tech billionaire Marc Benioff was in his element. At a Hawaiianthemed party in Davos hosted by his $134bn software company Salesforce, cocktails were being served as the Black Eyed Peas cranked out a set.

Outside, the snow lay thick on the ground but inside a nightclub in the Swiss ski resort Gavin Patterson, then chief executive of BT, was rubbing shoulders with Sergey Brin, Google co-founder and Lloyd Blankfein, then Goldman Sachs boss.

For Mr Patterson, however, the fun at the World Economic Forum (WEF) didn't last long.

Just four days later, BT's market value plunged by £8bn as investors digested news of a massive accounting scandal at its Italian division.

It was the beginning of a bubbling crisis at the UK telecom giant which ended in Mr Patterson's departure less than 18 months later, after investors made it clear they had lost confidence in his ability to lead BT through an ambitious overhaul.

This week, however, Patterson, 51, is back in the spotlight after it emerged Mr Benioff had picked him as Salesforce's new chairman for Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EMEA).

The appointment of a former FTSE 100 boss is a bold statement of intent from Salesforce, which is banking on a big expansion in the UK and Europe as a key plank of its growth strategy. The company, which occupies the upper floors of what is now called the Salesforce (née Heron) Tower on Bishopsgate in the City - Britain's third-tallest building - already employs more than 1,200 people in the UK and last year pledged to almost double that figure as it spends $2.5bn (£2bn) in Britain over the next five years. Despite the political crisis surrounding Brexit, most of Silicon Valley's tech giants are bulking up in Britain, drawn in by London's growing tech sector and a need to expand globally. But few are making appointments as high profile as Salesforce.

Patterson's appointment comes just weeks after the company said Jayne-Anne Gadhia, who ran Virgin Money for more than a decade, would become its UK chief executive. The company already counts former European competition and digital commissioner Neelie Kroes as a board member.

These are not ordinary regional hires, even for a company of Salesforce's size. But in the UK at least, they will bring credibility to a company that many still struggle to understand.

Founded by Benioff, whose fortune is estimated at $6.4bn, Salesforce may be the biggest and most powerful tech company you have never heard of.

It specialises in "customer relationship management" (CRM) software, used by businesses to keep track of and contact customers and potential clients. Its cloud-based software is used to store details, log communication and respond to questions or complaints. If you have filled in a website form or called a customer service hotline, there is a good chance the person on the other end was using Salesforce software.

If that sounds dull, Benioff - a consummate showman - has proved adept at building Salesforce into a successful business, roping in thousands of customers - large and small - into its orbit and generating spectacular growth in sales.

Much of that has been through Benioff 's genius for creating a spectacle - often with himself as a star attraction - and his fondness for spending big bucks doing so.

Back home in San Francisco, the company's annual Dreamforce event - a sort of software marketing circus meets music festival mash-up - has grown to legendary status, attracting nearly 200,000 people last year.

It featured Al Gore giving a speech on climate change and a group of Buddhist monks lecturing delegates on meditation and mindfulness. The contemplative atmosphere was later shattered by a set from Metallica.

In true tech mogul fashion, Benioff is also fond of big buildings. San Francisco's Salesforce Tower, the software giant's headquarters, is America's tallest office west of Chicago. It has a naming rights deal with the city's transport centre. And other Salesforce Towers can be found in Tokyo, New York and - soon - Dublin.

In 2014, the City of London Corporation denied a bid to rename the 46-storey Heron Tower, but later relented. It's a building Patterson is likely to be spending plenty of time in.

Salesforce's co-chief executives, Marc Benioff and Keith Block, said the former BT boss has "extensive experience in digital communications, customer engagement and systems delivery" and will be "a powerful addition to our EMEA team".

Salesforce did not invent CRM, but was a pioneer in selling its software as a subscription, allowing businesses to access it over the internet rather than installing it on their own servers.

It was a radical idea back in 2000, but cloud software is now common. Workers are on their phone as much as their desktop and need access to information anywhere. As a result, the industry is growing rapidly: Salesforce's revenues grew 22pc to $4bn in the second quarter of this year. But in its home market, growth is slowing.

In the Americas - which accounts for the bulk of Salesforce's revenues - growth was 20pc compared with 30pc for EMEA once foreign exchange fluctuations were stripped out.

"CRM is not a new category and the North American market is pretty saturated," says Mary Shea, an analyst at Forrester. "Companies of a certain size are going to have Salesforce or [Microsoft's rival software] Dynamics. Europe is the next opportunity for new customers."

But if the cloud means that business is just as easily done from the beach as the office, why is Salesforce relying on the rather old school business tactic of hiring big hitters - and their contact books - to expand in Europe? Patterson, in particular, has been hired partly to sign up multinational European companies, something Benioff will hope the ex-BT boss can carry over from the telecoms group's Global Services arm, which manages IT networks for large companies.

The division may not have been as cutting edge as Salesforce, but that may prove to be an advantage in Europe, where companies have been slower to embrace cloud technology and a lot of business is still done face to face.

Tech adoption in Europe lags fairly significantly," says Shea. "The local presence is important for a number of reasons, how you sell in North America versus Europe is very different. You can't sell everything over the phone."

Hiring from outside the tech industry may suit Benioff, who has been happy to distance himself from the rest of Silicon Valley. During a panel at last year's World Economic Forum, he attacked Google and Uber, despite executives from both companies sitting close to him, and called for more regulation of Big Tech. He has compared Facebook to the cigarette industry, suggesting the world will regret not curbing it sooner.

But in one way at least, Salesforce may not be so different to some of its Californian neighbours. In recent years it has lost money as often as it has turned a profit, and its soaring share price has instead been based on growing revenues, says IDC analyst Jordan Jewell. "They're keeping this cycle going and they can't slow down," he says, pointing out that the company spends around half of its revenues on sales and marketing alone.

As its home market slows down, an experienced salesman like Patterson will be crucial to growing Salesforce into a global phenomenon.

'The local presence is important for a number of reasons. You can't sell everything over the phone'

Gavin Patterson, the former BT chief, has joined Marc Benioff, right, at SalesforceSalesforce isn't a household name, but its founder has a fondness for creating a spectacle and the company holds an annual Dreamforce event which last year featured Metallica

urn:contentItem:5XSP-JG01-JCJY-G206-00000-00Tech tycoon Saul Klein: 'The UK's tech industry is light years ahead of the rest of Europe'2019-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1Tech tycoon Saul Klein: 'The UK's tech industry is light years ahead of the rest of Europe'By Robin Pagnamenta

"I'm not a climber," smiles Saul Klein, casting an eye outside as dusk falls over Kings Cross. "But part of this is just realising how much further you can go."

It's his last day in the office before he heads off for Christmas, but the 49-year-old investor behind Skype, Lovefilm, Citymapper and a string of other well-known UK technology businesses is in effusive mood.

Dressed in a grey T-shirt and jeans while seated in the sleek offices of Local Globe, his venture capital firm, Klein says three years after the Brexit vote and days after Boris Johnson romped to victory in the General Election, Britain's technology industry is in "rude health".

Investment into UK technology companies has more than doubled since the referendum, hitting a record £9bn this year - more than any other European country and demolishing fears over the potential negative fallout from Brexit.

The opportunity for further growth is vast, he beams - and the UK should grasp it with both hands.

"I think we are in an incredibly strong position," says Johannesburg-born Klein, a father of three children. "And we've been in that position for a surprisingly long time."

Klein, who also serves as an advisor to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport and the Government Digital Service (DCMS), claims Britain's tech industry is now so far ahead of its European rivals that comparisons with its equivalents in France or Germany are pointless.

"London's got 45 unicorns [technology start-ups worth more than $1bn (£770m) each]," he says.

"There's no other city in Europe other than Berlin that is in double digits - and that double digit is 10. Thirty-eight percent of all the unicorns in Europe are in the UK, and 30pc of the 'futurecorns' [companies with potential to exceed $1bn in valuation] worth $50m to $800m are here."

"So not only is the UK light years ahead of the rest of Europe and Israel, across every dimension, even in the last five years its lead has just been accelerating."

Klein, whose father Robin is also a venture capitalist and a venture partner at Index Ventures, continues: "So the real comparison is regional cities in the UK compared to capital cities in Europe. Right? So Oxbridge has nine, Berlin has 10. Manchester has five. Amsterdam has six."

According to KPMG, London ranks third in the world as a technology innovation hub while the UK as a whole ranks fourth behind only the US, China and India.

Britain's fertile tech scene represents a huge contrast to 17 years ago, when Klein returned to Britain from a spell living in Boston and Seattle, where he experienced the first dotcom investment boom - and its subsequent bust in 2000-01 - first hand.

"When I came back to the UK in 2002, there wasn't much of an ecosystem to speak of - or at least it was very, very nascent," he says.

"Most people were kind of dancing on the grave of the internet, like 'stupid kids - we knew they were full of shit. Thank god they're gone'."

A Cambridge University graduate - who studied English Literature not Computer Science - Klein has arguably surfed the wave of Britain's technology boom more successfully than anyone else.

His first big success came after an early investment in Skype, the video chat service, which was sold to Ebay for $4.2bn in 2005.

"That also made me realise that you could build a global winner from the UK and Europe.

"Because Skype was was global. You could build a company that someone else put an extraordinary value on - $4.2bn which even in today's money is a very decent exits, but in 2005, it was really big."

He says it was the alumni from Skype as well as Lovefilm and a string of other early London-based startup success stories who have gone on to found a new generation of companies and have fuelled the industry's growth.

As in Silicon Valley, the UK now has a significant pool of talent to draw from with experience of building tech start-ups, which is helping fuel a virtuous circle of new company formation, especially when founders exit and recycle the proceeds into new companies.

He says more than 50,000 people in the UK have now had experience of working for a technology "unicorn" and two million people work for tech companies while about one million job openings exist in the industry.

What about the impact of Brexit on confidence in the UK?

Klein shrugs and looks relaxed. "The referendum vote was on June 23, 2016. You know, the amount of venture capital coming into the market the year after that increased. The amount of venture capital coming in the year after that increased and the year after that it increased again."

Warming to his theme, he continues: "So quite frankly, whatever the political weather, the UK's strength now lies in an ecosystem it's taken 20 years to build, that now has a disproportionate supply of venture capital, a disproportionate supply of unicorns, futurecorns and exited unicorns."

French and German efforts to lure startups across the channel simply won't change this fundamental reality, he says.

"A couple of years ago at the height of Macron and Merkel, there was a lot of 'come to Paris, come to Berlin'. In the UK, we weren't playing to our strengths and the strength really is the facts. You know, we're not throwing in lunch at the Elysee Palace. It's the facts: Paris is Oxbridge, when it comes to unicorns. London's on another planet. This is a network effects industry where the ecosystems really, really matter."

So what should Britain aim to do next? How can it build on its record of success in a future outside the EU.

Klein, who is also a non executive at Kano Computing, the chairman of Seedcamp, a board member at both MyHeritage and Mind Candy, and a trustee at Comic Relief, believes a clear opportunity exists for the UK to adopt a leadership position.

"The area where the UK can and always has punched above its weight is in terms of value systems - rule of law, democracy, governance," he says, stressing that traditionally this is not a field where either the US or China has excelled.

"The UK and London has a 500 year track record. We've had our ups and downs but generally the UK is globally recognised as pretty good at governance. So we're now moving into an era where the governance of technology is maybe more fundamental than the technology itself."

He believes the UK has an enormous opportunity to influence and establish governance norms for technology that could have a global impact.

"We're in a moment in history where people are crying out for some structure."

That's why he believes the UK should spearhead the global push to create a regulatory framework for Big Tech - an area in which it is already leading the way with publication of the Online Harms White Paper produced by the Department for Media, Culture and Sport (DCMS).

The creation of a new Centre for Data Ethics and Innovation is another step in the right direction, he says.

"Where do we want to be number one? I would say values," he says.

And how should the UK technology industry view Britain's new government and an end to over three years of political uncertainty?

"For me, it's very simple. Just get back on the front foot, which I think people already starting to do."

urn:contentItem:5VMS-M0F1-DYTY-C22G-00000-00Tech Unchecked;The over-mighty digital giants need tighter regulation2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. 27Tech UncheckedThe over-mighty digital giants need tighter regulation

Bullies have to be called out and confronted. Philip Hammond, the chancellor, took an important step in that direction yesterday by demanding a review of the competition-distorting behaviour of the tech giants. The call to arms included tighter controls on online advertising revenue and tax dodging schemes as well as the protection of the public from online harassment.

The chancellor commissioned a report last year from a panel of economists, led by the Harvard academic Jason Furman. "There are a lot of benefits to the digital sector," says Mr Furman, "but when you have these large companies that are so dominant in so many markets, consumers do not have the choices they should have." If his conclusions are adopted, some blatant monopolistic practices of the tech giants could be open to robust challenge. They include a code of conduct to be policed by an independent regulator.

The digital economy has been at the heart of an extraordinary transformation of society, providing services and products at low prices. The cost of starting and scaling up a business has been cut with the help of cloud computing and digital comparison tools. Yet this is due overwhelmingly to the US giants that have squeezed the oxygen out of smaller start-ups. When growth threatens to slow, the whale swallows the minnows. Over the past decade the big five, Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft, have swallowed more than 400 companies that could have been rivals.

The report is an answer to a steady drumbeat of discontent. One is big tech's refusal to accept that they are publishers and curate their content. Young users, in particular, are vulnerable to unfiltered online abuse. It took years of pressure before Instagram banned graphic images of self-harm. Furthermore the tax paid by these companies is often derisory. There is a growing sense among users that their privacy is not adequately respected and that complaints are brushed off.

Last month the Cairncross Review, which investigated threats to high-quality journalism in Britain, warned that the domination of digital advertising by Google and Facebook was making it difficult for publishers and newspapers to survive. Out of a British digital advertising spend of £11.55 billion in 2017, Google and Facebook took 54 per cent. The Furman Review takes up the issue. Google, it suggests, will tighten its grip on advertising as technology becomes more sophisticated. Not only publishers but consumers and advertisers will lose out to the Google business model. Voices, including News Corp, owner of The Times, are calling for the break-up of Google, saying that its dominance "strikes at the heart of our system of democracy". Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic presidential runner, has also called for the dismantling of the tech giants. The Furman report stops short of this, saying that it would make the business environment "more uncertain and particularly risky". Yet a consensus is emerging that tighter regulation is needed even though no one is quite sure how to get there. The chancellor, too, may come to the conclusion that these giants are too big, too predatory and willing to destroy too many public-interest publishers. If so, curbing them, or indeed breaking them up, may be the best solution.

urn:contentItem:5VMS-M0F1-DYTY-C2JR-00000-00Tech Unchecked;The over-mighty digital giants need tighter regulation2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 27Tech UncheckedThe over-mighty digital giants need tighter regulation

Bullies have to be called out and confronted. Philip Hammond, the chancellor, took an important step in that direction yesterday by demanding a review of the competition-distorting behaviour of the tech giants. The call to arms included tighter controls on online advertising revenue and tax dodging schemes as well as the protection of the public from online harassment.

The chancellor commissioned a report last year from a panel of economists, led by the Harvard academic Jason Furman. "There are a lot of benefits to the digital sector," says Mr Furman, "but when you have these large companies that are so dominant in so many markets, consumers do not have the choices they should have." If his conclusions are adopted, some blatant monopolistic practices of the tech giants could be open to robust challenge. They include a code of conduct to be policed by an independent regulator.

The digital economy has been at the heart of an extraordinary transformation of society, providing services and products at low prices. The cost of starting and scaling up a business has been cut with the help of cloud computing and digital comparison tools. Yet this is due overwhelmingly to the US giants that have squeezed the oxygen out of smaller start-ups. When growth threatens to slow, the whale swallows the minnows. Over the past decade the big five, Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft, have swallowed more than 400 companies that could have been rivals.

The report is an answer to a steady drumbeat of discontent. One is big tech's refusal to accept that they are publishers and curate their content. Young users, in particular, are vulnerable to unfiltered online abuse. It took years of pressure before Instagram banned graphic images of self-harm. Furthermore the tax paid by these companies is often derisory. There is a growing sense among users that their privacy is not adequately respected and that complaints are brushed off.

Last month the Cairncross Review, which investigated threats to high-quality journalism in Britain, warned that the domination of digital advertising by Google and Facebook was making it difficult for publishers and newspapers to survive. Out of a British digital advertising spend of £11.55 billion in 2017, Google and Facebook took 54 per cent. The Furman Review takes up the issue. Google, it suggests, will tighten its grip on advertising as technology becomes more sophisticated. Not only publishers but consumers and advertisers will lose out to the Google business model. Voices, including News Corp, owner of The Times, are calling for the break-up of Google, saying that its dominance "strikes at the heart of our system of democracy". Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic presidential runner, has also called for the dismantling of the tech giants. The Furman report stops short of this, saying that it would make the business environment "more uncertain and particularly risky". Yet a consensus is emerging that tighter regulation is needed even though no one is quite sure how to get there. The chancellor, too, may come to the conclusion that these giants are too big, too predatory and willing to destroy too many public-interest publishers. If so, curbing them, or indeed breaking them up, may be the best solution.

urn:contentItem:5WMY-VH61-JBK8-937X-00000-00Tech under fire Feds target Amazon, Apple, Google & F'book2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisSports+Late City FinalPg. 27Tech under fire Feds target Amazon, Apple, Google & F'bookNicolas Vega

The Justice Department announced Tuesday that it is launching a probe into big tech companies' efforts to reduce competition and stifle innovation - raising the heat on an already-embattled industry.

The DOJ's antitrust division will determine whether "market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers," it said in a press release.

Though the department did not single out any specific company, the reviews will focus on Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon, according to the Wall Street Journal.

Shares of Amazon and Facebook both dipped close to 1.5 percent in late trading following the news. Apple and Google parent Alphabet were down 0.4 percent and 0.9 percent, respectively.

"Without the discipline of meaningful market-based competition, digital platforms may act in ways that are not responsive to consumer demands," Makan Delrahim, head of the DOJ's antitrust team, said in a statement.

The review will consider "the widespread concerns that consumers, businesses, and entrepreneurs have expressed about search, social media, and some retail services online," the DOJ said.

The agency has the authority to push to break up companies it finds hold too much power, like it did with AT&T in the 1980s, although that process took nearly a decade.

The DOJ crackdown comes as Silicon Valley's top companies face unprecedented scrutiny of their business practices, including claims from President Trump that tech giants meddle with his coverage and Twitter following - and calls by presidential candidates to break up the nation's biggest tech companies.

Facebook, meanwhile, is still facing fallout for letting British consulting firm Cambridge Analytica hoover up the personal data of nearly 90 million Facebook users leading up to the 2016 presidential election - including a record $5 billion fine from the Federal Trade Commission that is expected to be announced Wednesday.

Trump slammed Google last year for prioritizing negative coverage of him in search results, and accused Twitter in April of deleting his followers.

Google has denied "a political agenda," and Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey held an impromptu sitdown with Trump to explain that Twitter was purging spam accounting.

Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, meanwhile, has made the breakup of big tech companies - including Google, Apple and Amazon - one of her top initiatives.

"Today's big tech companies have too much power - over our economy, our society, & our democracy," Warren tweeted in May. "They've bulldozed competition, used our private info for profit, hurt small businesses & stifled innovation. It's time to #BreakUpBigTech."

It's not just US politicians and regulators that are pressuring Silicon Valley. The European Commission last week opened a formal antitrust investigation into whether Amazon uses data from independent retailers who sell on its marketplace to compete against them.

And in July, the EC slapped Google with a $4.9 billion fine for pitching its Android operating system for phones as "open" while placing restrictions on phone makers to ensure its internet browser, Google Chrome, was the only browser pre-installed on Android phones.

Apple is reportedly being probed by the EC over complaints by Swedish company Spotify that its App Store rules favor its own apps over those from competitors.

It was previously reported that the DOJ was looking into investigating Alphabet, run by Google co-founder Larry Page, and Apple for potential anti-competitive practices - while leaving probes into Facebook and Amazon to the FTC.

The DOJ's announcement arrives a week after President Trump tweeted that his administration will probe billionaire Peter Thiel's claim that Google has "seemingly treasonous" ties with China.

BARTIROMO: Then, there's Iran, America is pressuring its allies to stop importing oil from Iran ahead of the reinstated sanctions next week. Iran is threatening unspecified countermeasures. What might they be? Your reaction to Iran.

PERRY: Maria, the President has been very straightforward, he's been very blunt with the Iranians. The destabilization of the Middle East and other places around the world, he's just not going to put up with it. And whatever we need to do to send a message that Iran can be -- you know, they can -- they can be participants in the world order, they can be participants in that part of world and do it in a civil and a peaceful thoughtful way. If they don't, the President has been very clear, there will be powerful sanctions, there will be strong pushback from United States and our allies, sending the message -- this isn't about the Iranian people, this is about the leadership in that country, the revolutionary guard in particular, you know, act decent in the world you live in and you can expect to do business with the United States. If you don't, there will be hell to pay.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, he has been very clear. Secretary, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

PERRY: Good. Maria, so long.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it, Secretary Rick Perry joining us there. Coming up, getting rewarded for wearing clothes, how Tommy Hilfiger is giving customer prices for wearing its brand, coming up. Then Paul Ryan poking some fun at himself, the House Speaker's hilarious response to reading mean tweets about himself, later this hour. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets cheering the thaw in trade tensions between the U.S. and the European Union, following President Trump's discussion with E.U. Commissioner Jean-Claude Juncker. We want to talk more about that in a minute. We're going to welcome Stuart Varney. By the way, yesterday, Stuart said all I want to see is Juncker and President Trump walk out with smiles and be happy, and the markets are going to turn, and that's exactly what happened.

BELL: Sounds like is exactly what happened.

BARTIROMO: Look at the big reaction at the -- after the close.

BELL: There was. I would have like to see --

BARTIROMO: No, even before the close, sorry.

BELL: -- more clarity on the auto tariffs, but you know, this is a great step in the right direction.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, let's bring in Stuart Varney who called it, host of "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, you called it. This time yesterday, you and I posed the question, what happens if we get some good news on trade, does the market pop? I said, yes. I think you said, yes, too, Maria. Come on.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But you -- but you had the idea, and that was a great idea.

VARNEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Because it's true, that's exactly what the market wanted, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, that's right. And now, there may be a little bit of a follow on today. May I remind you that there's a delegation from Mexico in D.C. right now, talking trade, they want to wrap up a trade deal, a bilateral trade deal, you could possibly get some more smiling faces, not necessarily the news conference, but some smiley faces when they walk out of the meeting. That could mean another small leg up for the overall market. But, to me, the most important thing in that trade deal is that they, the Europe (AUDIO GAP) take that China, and they're going to take a lot of our energy, natural gas, take that Russia. Seems to me that the Europeans blinked and Trump won again. That's the way it seems to me.

BARTIROMO: Well, yes. We'll see. I mean, they said that they're going to work towards zero tariffs, but let's not forget the aluminum and steel tariffs are still in place, and they said also, Dagen, that it's non-auto. That's really what the sticking point was, the auto (INAUDIBLE)

VARNEY: Yes, yes.

MCDOWELL: That rally was purely based on the fact that this is a de- escalation of tensions, it is a truce on additional tariffs, particularly the threat of tariffs on the European automobile imports. But, again, we're still watching because these steel and aluminum tariffs -- what?

VARNEY: Well, look, you're not going to have a tit-for-tat escalation with Europe.

BARTIROMO: No, right.

VARNEY: That's not going to happen, they agreed not to do that yesterday. That was the heart of the good news.

MCDOWELL: But as one of our viewers just --

BARTIROMO: And that's when markets rallied -- yes.

MCDOWELL: As one of our viewers just tweeted, it's time for more go than show. It like let's actually get deals done and let's alleviate some of the pain from the steel and aluminum tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's doing it. I mean, Stuart just said the Mexicans are in the White House today and we keep hearing HHS secretary that we speak with, Stuart, that they feel really good about a deal with Mexico over the near-term, and they assume that Canada is going to get in line as well once the Mexico deal is done.

VARNEY: Oh, that's the way it looks. The incoming -- the new President of Mexico has -- his top trade advisor has publicly said, they want to wrap up a deal, a bilateral deal with United States in a matter of months. Now, that's a big deal. If that happens, well, the Canadians, they're going to have to come on board somehow or other. I think it's progress all around.

BARTIROMO: Wilbur Ross was on the show earlier, he said, look, Mexico is a lot more complicated than Canada, and we know that, because Mexico, you know, there are different deals in terms of workers, where car will originate in terms of production. So -- but he, too, was pretty optimistic about a deal with Mexico. Stuart, I know you're going to have a lot more in about 10 minutes. We'll see you then.

VARNEY: Yes, you got it. Sure thing. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. So, join Stuart in just 10 minutes' time. But first, there's this, Paul Ryan goes from House Speaker to standup comedian.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: Paul Ryan could be a live action Disney villain. #WidowsPeak" They used to call me Eddie Munster so it's not too much of a stretch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More of the tweets, coming up. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Investigators are now focused on digital information in the search for a missing college student in Iowa. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl?

CASONE: Well, using search warrants, authorities are analyzing 20-year- old, Mollie Tibbett's digit info, that includes her Fitbit which she always wore, her Instagram and her Snapchat data to track her whereabouts and at least put a timeline together of her whereabouts the night that she disappeared while out on a run. She was last seen jogging in her hometown of Brooklyn, Iowa about a week ago. All the information is a key piece of the investigation, it is not being made public, at this time, but they are getting data off of her devices.

All right. Well, check out this incredible video, dozens of people forming a human chain to save swimmers from a riptide. You can see them locking arms up the coast of Emerald Isle, this is in North Carolina, by the way. Emergency crews also got involved in some of these rescues. Sadly, they were unable to revive a 41-year-old man after they pulled him out of the water. The water looks, to me, it's terrifying. Swimmers a lot of times did not heed the beach safety warnings, so that's kind of what happened there.

All right, Tommy Hilfiger is offering rewards to customers who wear its new line of smart clothing that comes with a smart chip tracking how often customers wear it. So you earn points that can be used to buy concert tickets or merchandise. The brand hopes that interest in the new line is going to create a microcommunity of brand ambassadors.

And then, there is this, this is fun, House Speaker Paul Ryan posted a video reading mean tweets about himself, taking inspiration from the popular Jimmy Kimmel segment. Watch!

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RYAN: Paul Ryan could be live action Disney villain. #WidowsPeak. Woodchucks eating Paul Ryan's car has given me hope for the future. My car dealer as well. I want to high-five Paul Ryan's face with a shovel, just hard enough to make him see birdies. Take that smug look.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(LAUGHTER)

CASONE: There's the look. With Ryan not seeking re-election in November, maybe some of these critics are going to ease up on him. At least he proved he can take a serious joke or tell one, if you want to put it that way, Maria. It's really funny.

BARTIROMO: That is very funny. Maybe he's just taking it all in stride now that he knows he's on his way out.

CASONE: Why not? Relax about it, all right.

BARTIROMO: Thanks, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Take a break. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Great show, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

MCDOWELL: Love you much every day.

BARTIROMO: Right back at you.

MCDOWELL: Smart, hard-working lady. The best in the business.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for joining us, everybody. Have a great day. Go seize that day. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Seize the day. Yes, indeed.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria. And good morning, everyone. Let's get right at it. This stuff is very important for everyone. Facebook slowing down, and that spells real trouble for the company and its investors. We used a huge --

END
