Trade Ceasefire; Jerry Jones Says Dallas Cowboys Will Stand for Anthem; House GOP Versus the DOJ; Pompeo Tough on Russia; Toronto Seeks Handgun Sales Ban After Deadly Shooting; Trump's Hollywood Star Vandalized Again; Waymo And Wal-Mart Team Up; Summer Fun With KalahariLanhamFULL TEXT

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: All right. It's time to turn it over to Maria Bartiromo. Good morning Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday and good morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 26th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Facebook unfriended on Wall Street that's for sure, the stock is plunging this morning on the edge of the plunge last night, disappointing sales and revenue guidance. Nearly $150 billion wiped from market value in the afterhours trading session. Incredible drop on Facebook, down seventeen and a quarter percent right now.

Facebook setting the tone for the rest of the sector for sure, the big names in technology this morning under pressure. Take a look at Twitter down three percent and Alphabet, parents of Google down and a third percent. Amazon will report its earnings after the close tonight. Ahead of that, the stock is down one and a three quarters percent.

Broader markets this morning look like this, in fact, it's a mixed story. Dow Industrials are up 50 points but look at the NASDAQ where we've got so many technology names there and that is down almost one percent, 60 points lower on the NASDAQ this morning.

There's wild session on Wall Street yesterday, stock surge in the last 30 minutes of trading. On news of a softening trade dispute between the U.S. and the E.U. President Trump talking about working toward zero tariffs. Yesterday, the Dow Industrials up 172 points at the close with that huge rally in the final 30 minutes. The NASDAQ was up 91 points, better than one percent.

In Europe this morning investors are waiting to hear from the European Central Bank in a sense of when rising interest rates might be on the horizon. What happens next with European stimulus. The European markets are fractionally better on the session with the CAC Quarante in Paris up three quarters of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up one and a third percent.

In Asia overnight markets mostly lower at the close, as you can see best performer was Korea. Kospi Index up three quarters of one percent.

Easing trade tensions, President Trump and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker putting new tariffs on hold as they work to negotiate a trade deal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Over the years the United States has been losing hundreds of billions of dollars with the European Union and we just want it to be a level playing field for our farmers, for our manufacturers, for everybody.

And we also want a big beneficiary to be the European Union, so we think it can be good for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This morning we take a look at the key issues at stake coming up right now. Plus, an explosion near the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, the only person injured was the bomber who allegedly set off the device. We have the very latest on this investigation coming up.

President Trump star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame destroyed. Take a look, the suspect using a pick axe and later charged with felony vandalism. We will tell you who is bailing him out of jail this morning, coming up.

Plus, Cowboys owner Jerry Jones standing firm in his support for the national anthem, he says all players will be required to stand during the national anthem.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former NFL Star and the Brewer Group CEO, Jack Brewer with us this morning. Along with CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: A lot of news this morning.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: Yes. It's going to be a good one.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it really is. Facebook obviously the story of the moment Lindsey. Is that going to be an overhang over the -- over the broader markets in your view?

BELL: You know what, I think it will be an overhang on the tech sector today but hopefully Amazon can turn the ship around this evening when they report results.

I think one thing to note about tech and the overall market in general is going into the earning season. I was really concerned about CAPEX declining because it had been up on average 40 percent over the last three quarters.

But you saw even though Facebook's numbers weren't great and the outlook was poor, they increase CAPEX spending, so did Google. They more -- they like doubled it. And then you're also seeing industrial companies increased their CAPEX, so it's very good for future growth.

BARTIROMO: That conference call really sounded wild last night Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Again, there's an incredible, what they call in journalism a tick tock in the Wall Street Journal about that conference call. How Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg come on the call and talk about how awesome business is and Instagram is so amazing.

And then the chief financial officer comes on and drops one bomb after another in terms of talking about the growth -- revenue growth rate isn't just slowing in the second quarter but it's going to continue to do that in the third and fourth quarter.

There was trouble because of the new European regulations. Currency headwinds, new privacy options for users, he -- that was part of the blame but he said that new ad formats such as those within the Instagram stories are not pulling the same amount of money as ads shown in Facebook and Instagram feeds. So there's a lot of bad news in there.

Just putting exclamation point on it, we had Facebook at a new all-time high yesterday. In one day the stock is almost in bear market territory. In one day it went from an all-time high to nearly a bear market which would be a 20 percent drop.

BARTIROMO: Seventy percent drop right now and I guess it became clear last night that all those investment into security, into privacy as a result of what's been going on with privacy is going to cut into growth.

Bottom line, Facebook is not going to be immune to this. You mentioned story segments section in Instagram, that's not going to bring the margins that the rest of the company has been bringing, that's the bottom line.

MCDOWELL: Right. So they're going to have to figure out--again, because the story is a memo--it's sort of an offshoot of Snapchat, they put those in place to take on Snapchat because they're --

BARTIROMO: Where it goes away in 24 hours.

MCDOWELL: Right. They're -- but I -- following those stories and using them, there are ways that they can better integrate the actual -- to monetize those and then to place the ads in those stories. So they're asking for a long runway. Well today, investors are not giving an answer on them.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BELL: It says margins are getting cut going forward because of all this and their investments especially in security.

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, this is the group that has been the leadership in terms of gains for the broader markets. This is where the money has been moving. So there's probably expectations up here and the realities over here.

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And just real quick, because I'm not a phony, that was an outstanding news coming out of the White House yesterday, that's exactly what investors needed to hear in terms of cooling the tariff tensions, the trade tensions and giving kind of some insights to the road ahead, a renegotiating trade deals. Maybe even with Europe which is a goal but then NAFTA and then taking on China.

BARTIROMO: Markets obviously reacted to that immediately. The president comes out with Mr. Juncker and starts talking about working towards zero tariffs which by the way was exactly what the president has been trying to get for -- from a lot of these players.

Yesterday we heard from a number of players that Mexico may be next. We'll see if they can do a deal with Mexico and then Canada follows along. This whole wild, you know, upset over the tariffs will go away. So we'll see. And then there's the NFL Jack Brewer, what do you think about Jerry Jones?

BREWER: Ah, it's expected. You know, Jerry has -- he stood strong, this is not a change in his approach, in his tone in regards to this whole situation. You know, it's one thing to talk about kneeling with the goal and to actually pass a policy then pull it back, go back and forth.

I'm interested in owner seat like Jerry Jones. His fan base wants to see his players stand for the national anthem, I understand that. I know, I've said this before, right, people, this is America, you can stand, you can kneel, you can do what you want. But if your boss tells you to stand, you stand.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you stand. And that's what we are this morning. A lot of stories to cover.

We want to kick it off right here with our trade ceasefire story, top of news. President Trump headed to Granite City, Illinois this morning where he is set to tour a steel mill that is now boosting production following the president's move to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports earlier this year. This visit coming a day after announcing a breakthrough in trade talks with the European Union.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We agreed today first of all to work together towards zero tariffs, zero nontariff barriers, and zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods, thank you.

While we are working on this, we will not go against the spirit of this agreement unless either party terminates the negotiation. So we're starting the negotiation right now but we know very much where it's going.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Still, the tariffs on aluminum and steel are costing American companies. Both Coca Cola and General Motors now say they will have to raise prices on their products in large part because of the president's trade fights.

Joining us right now to weigh in from Washington is Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Mr. Secretary, it's good to see you this morning, thanks so much for joining us.

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. COMMERCE SECRETARY: Thank you for having me on Maria.

BARTIROMO: Well, this was a big deal yesterday with the president and Mr. Juncker. Can you go through what was -- what was agreed upon?

ROSS: Surely. The objectives of a new trade negotiation have been very firmly set, zero -- we're going towards zero tariffs, zero nontariff trade barriers, zero subsidies.

So that should really level the playing field and enable American companies to be fully competitive and get the kind of market access that they need. Meanwhile, the steel and aluminum tariffs stay in place, we will continue pursuing our investigation of the Automotive 232 and hopefully these negotiations will be completed fairly quickly so that we can get to the stable situation.

BARTIROMO: So is the plan to eventually do away with the aluminum and steel tariffs or the auto tariffs? I mean, even on light trucks the U.S. charges, what, 255 percent, right?

ROSS: Well you notice on light trucks, the -- there was an exception for automotive products. It's said we'd work toward zero tariffs on nonautomotive industrial products. And to steel and aluminum, there's no attention to abandon those industries.

So the president is very happy with the progress they have made and opening new facilities. I'm joining them today as we go out to visit one that had just recently been reopened. He's not going to do anything to destroy steel and aluminum from their new found substance.

BARTIROMO: Was there a timeline discussed Secretary in terms of when we might see actual clarity on what the trade deal will look like between the U.S. and the E.U.?

ROSS: There's no precise time table set because that's not a meaningful thing. But the president made it very clear he is not going to sit around for the normal two, three years to get a trade deal done.

Since we've got the broad principals agreed, it now should be more filling in the blanks than starting from ground zero.

BARTIROMO: And what do you think about these tariffs hitting Detroit? General Motors, Ford, and FiatChrysler all yesterday lowered guidance. Are you suggesting their full year outlook says they revealed lower than expected second quarter earnings, all of which were impacted by the rising cost of steel and aluminum.

So Mr. Secretary, will the president's negotiations with the E.U. reverse what's going on with the automakers? We are already seeing that they're expecting this to impact their business.

ROSS: Well, I have said before, the impact of steel and aluminum on the auto industry's cost is really fairly minor. It's about one percent on the cost of the vehicle.

So to the degree that that might be passed along, that's possible. But the offsetting thing is what you're seeing unemployment figures. Record low unemployment, more jobs available than there are people available to fill them for the first time ever.

Record low unemployment for African-Americans, for Hispanics, for women, for young people. I mean, the economy is booming and that's what's really important. The other important thing though is the president has made clear he's not going to abandon the industries that just has helped to revitalized.

BARTIROMO: Right. And what's the next priority then Wilbur? We've been talking a lot about the potential for a deal with Mexico. Is that the priority now as you continue to work with the E.U.?

ROSS: Well we're working on a lot of different fronts all at the same time. And that shows you the speed and the breath of the president's sculpt of these trace issues.

We have to get them fixed in a fairly short period of time. They've gone on too long, unchecked by prior administrations. As to Mexico, the new president very quickly appointed the team that would do the trade negotiations for him has made very clear he wants to get a deal done.

And he did all of this without even waiting for his inauguration. He'll be inaugurated on the first of December and it looks pretty clear that his goal would be to try to get something resolved between the United States and Mexico prior to even his inauguration.

BARTIROMO: So you think you -- is it fair to say then the change in leadership in Mexico also was very positive toward better relations with the U.S.?

ROSS: Well potentially so. It certainly has made us all feel a lot better than we did during some of the campaign rhetoric.

BARTIROMO: And you think that Canada will be close behind once you do do a deal -- a new NAFTA deal with Mexico?

ROSS: Well we hope so but the immediate focus is much more on Mexico. The issues there are more complex and we think we can get very good progress very quickly.

BARTIROMO: Understood. Let me move on to China Secretary, the president there said this morning that there would be no winner in a global trade war. Your reaction to what's coming out of China?

Do you feel that you've been able to move the needle yet in terms of their theft of intellectual property and technology?

ROSS: Well we haven't seen any formal steps to resolve those issues. But you see these repeated announcements coming out of China, things that they're doing with the banking system bolstering capital, bolstering liquidity.

Clearly, they're feeling a pressure from the tariffs that the president has put on and equally clearly they're having some difficulty implementing their retaliatory tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Do you feel better now that there's this agreement in place with the E.U. potentially teaming up with the E.U. against China to pressure China to stop bad behavior?

ROSS: Well as we know, the E.U. has suggested several times publicly that they hope they could resolve things with us so that they could join with us very aggressively in dealings with China.

We'll have to see what turns out from that but it certainly is a good step regardless what happens with China to move toward a level playing field and zero tariffs, zero nontariff barrier and zero subsidy environment with the E.U.

Trade Ceasefire; Jerry Jones Says Dallas Cowboys Will Stand for Anthem; House GOP Versus the DOJ; Pompeo Tough on Russia; Toronto Seeks Handgun Sales Ban After Deadly Shooting; Trump's Hollywood Star Vandalized Again; Waymo And Wal-Mart Team Up; Summer Fun With Kalahari2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisTech Under Pressure; U.S.-E.U. Trade Ceasefire; Jerry Jones Says Dallas Cowboys Will Stand for Anthem; House GOP Versus the DOJ; Pompeo Tough on Russia; Toronto Seeks Handgun Sales Ban After Deadly Shooting; Trump's Hollywood Star Vandalized Again; Waymo And Wal-Mart Team Up; Summer Fun With KalahariLanhamFULL TEXT

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: All right. It's time to turn it over to Maria Bartiromo. Good morning Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday and good morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 26th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Facebook unfriended on Wall Street that's for sure, the stock is plunging this morning on the edge of the plunge last night, disappointing sales and revenue guidance. Nearly $150 billion wiped from market value in the afterhours trading session. Incredible drop on Facebook, down seventeen and a quarter percent right now.

Facebook setting the tone for the rest of the sector for sure, the big names in technology this morning under pressure. Take a look at Twitter down three percent and Alphabet, parents of Google down and a third percent. Amazon will report its earnings after the close tonight. Ahead of that, the stock is down one and a three quarters percent.

Broader markets this morning look like this, in fact, it's a mixed story. Dow Industrials are up 50 points but look at the NASDAQ where we've got so many technology names there and that is down almost one percent, 60 points lower on the NASDAQ this morning.

There's wild session on Wall Street yesterday, stock surge in the last 30 minutes of trading. On news of a softening trade dispute between the U.S. and the E.U. President Trump talking about working toward zero tariffs. Yesterday, the Dow Industrials up 172 points at the close with that huge rally in the final 30 minutes. The NASDAQ was up 91 points, better than one percent.

In Europe this morning investors are waiting to hear from the European Central Bank in a sense of when rising interest rates might be on the horizon. What happens next with European stimulus. The European markets are fractionally better on the session with the CAC Quarante in Paris up three quarters of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up one and a third percent.

In Asia overnight markets mostly lower at the close, as you can see best performer was Korea. Kospi Index up three quarters of one percent.

Easing trade tensions, President Trump and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker putting new tariffs on hold as they work to negotiate a trade deal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Over the years the United States has been losing hundreds of billions of dollars with the European Union and we just want it to be a level playing field for our farmers, for our manufacturers, for everybody.

And we also want a big beneficiary to be the European Union, so we think it can be good for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This morning we take a look at the key issues at stake coming up right now. Plus, an explosion near the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, the only person injured was the bomber who allegedly set off the device. We have the very latest on this investigation coming up.

President Trump star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame destroyed. Take a look, the suspect using a pick axe and later charged with felony vandalism. We will tell you who is bailing him out of jail this morning, coming up.

Plus, Cowboys owner Jerry Jones standing firm in his support for the national anthem, he says all players will be required to stand during the national anthem.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former NFL Star and the Brewer Group CEO, Jack Brewer with us this morning. Along with CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: A lot of news this morning.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: Yes. It's going to be a good one.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it really is. Facebook obviously the story of the moment Lindsey. Is that going to be an overhang over the -- over the broader markets in your view?

BELL: You know what, I think it will be an overhang on the tech sector today but hopefully Amazon can turn the ship around this evening when they report results.

I think one thing to note about tech and the overall market in general is going into the earning season. I was really concerned about CAPEX declining because it had been up on average 40 percent over the last three quarters.

But you saw even though Facebook's numbers weren't great and the outlook was poor, they increase CAPEX spending, so did Google. They more -- they like doubled it. And then you're also seeing industrial companies increased their CAPEX, so it's very good for future growth.

BARTIROMO: That conference call really sounded wild last night Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Again, there's an incredible, what they call in journalism a tick tock in the Wall Street Journal about that conference call. How Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg come on the call and talk about how awesome business is and Instagram is so amazing.

And then the chief financial officer comes on and drops one bomb after another in terms of talking about the growth -- revenue growth rate isn't just slowing in the second quarter but it's going to continue to do that in the third and fourth quarter.

There was trouble because of the new European regulations. Currency headwinds, new privacy options for users, he -- that was part of the blame but he said that new ad formats such as those within the Instagram stories are not pulling the same amount of money as ads shown in Facebook and Instagram feeds. So there's a lot of bad news in there.

Just putting exclamation point on it, we had Facebook at a new all-time high yesterday. In one day the stock is almost in bear market territory. In one day it went from an all-time high to nearly a bear market which would be a 20 percent drop.

BARTIROMO: Seventy percent drop right now and I guess it became clear last night that all those investment into security, into privacy as a result of what's been going on with privacy is going to cut into growth.

Bottom line, Facebook is not going to be immune to this. You mentioned story segments section in Instagram, that's not going to bring the margins that the rest of the company has been bringing, that's the bottom line.

MCDOWELL: Right. So they're going to have to figure out--again, because the story is a memo--it's sort of an offshoot of Snapchat, they put those in place to take on Snapchat because they're --

BARTIROMO: Where it goes away in 24 hours.

MCDOWELL: Right. They're -- but I -- following those stories and using them, there are ways that they can better integrate the actual -- to monetize those and then to place the ads in those stories. So they're asking for a long runway. Well today, investors are not giving an answer on them.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BELL: It says margins are getting cut going forward because of all this and their investments especially in security.

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, this is the group that has been the leadership in terms of gains for the broader markets. This is where the money has been moving. So there's probably expectations up here and the realities over here.

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And just real quick, because I'm not a phony, that was an outstanding news coming out of the White House yesterday, that's exactly what investors needed to hear in terms of cooling the tariff tensions, the trade tensions and giving kind of some insights to the road ahead, a renegotiating trade deals. Maybe even with Europe which is a goal but then NAFTA and then taking on China.

BARTIROMO: Markets obviously reacted to that immediately. The president comes out with Mr. Juncker and starts talking about working towards zero tariffs which by the way was exactly what the president has been trying to get for -- from a lot of these players.

Yesterday we heard from a number of players that Mexico may be next. We'll see if they can do a deal with Mexico and then Canada follows along. This whole wild, you know, upset over the tariffs will go away. So we'll see. And then there's the NFL Jack Brewer, what do you think about Jerry Jones?

BREWER: Ah, it's expected. You know, Jerry has -- he stood strong, this is not a change in his approach, in his tone in regards to this whole situation. You know, it's one thing to talk about kneeling with the goal and to actually pass a policy then pull it back, go back and forth.

I'm interested in owner seat like Jerry Jones. His fan base wants to see his players stand for the national anthem, I understand that. I know, I've said this before, right, people, this is America, you can stand, you can kneel, you can do what you want. But if your boss tells you to stand, you stand.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you stand. And that's what we are this morning. A lot of stories to cover.

We want to kick it off right here with our trade ceasefire story, top of news. President Trump headed to Granite City, Illinois this morning where he is set to tour a steel mill that is now boosting production following the president's move to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports earlier this year. This visit coming a day after announcing a breakthrough in trade talks with the European Union.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We agreed today first of all to work together towards zero tariffs, zero nontariff barriers, and zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods, thank you.

While we are working on this, we will not go against the spirit of this agreement unless either party terminates the negotiation. So we're starting the negotiation right now but we know very much where it's going.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Still, the tariffs on aluminum and steel are costing American companies. Both Coca Cola and General Motors now say they will have to raise prices on their products in large part because of the president's trade fights.

Joining us right now to weigh in from Washington is Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Mr. Secretary, it's good to see you this morning, thanks so much for joining us.

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. COMMERCE SECRETARY: Thank you for having me on Maria.

BARTIROMO: Well, this was a big deal yesterday with the president and Mr. Juncker. Can you go through what was -- what was agreed upon?

ROSS: Surely. The objectives of a new trade negotiation have been very firmly set, zero -- we're going towards zero tariffs, zero nontariff trade barriers, zero subsidies.

So that should really level the playing field and enable American companies to be fully competitive and get the kind of market access that they need. Meanwhile, the steel and aluminum tariffs stay in place, we will continue pursuing our investigation of the Automotive 232 and hopefully these negotiations will be completed fairly quickly so that we can get to the stable situation.

BARTIROMO: So is the plan to eventually do away with the aluminum and steel tariffs or the auto tariffs? I mean, even on light trucks the U.S. charges, what, 255 percent, right?

ROSS: Well you notice on light trucks, the -- there was an exception for automotive products. It's said we'd work toward zero tariffs on nonautomotive industrial products. And to steel and aluminum, there's no attention to abandon those industries.

So the president is very happy with the progress they have made and opening new facilities. I'm joining them today as we go out to visit one that had just recently been reopened. He's not going to do anything to destroy steel and aluminum from their new found substance.

BARTIROMO: Was there a timeline discussed Secretary in terms of when we might see actual clarity on what the trade deal will look like between the U.S. and the E.U.?

ROSS: There's no precise time table set because that's not a meaningful thing. But the president made it very clear he is not going to sit around for the normal two, three years to get a trade deal done.

Since we've got the broad principals agreed, it now should be more filling in the blanks than starting from ground zero.

BARTIROMO: And what do you think about these tariffs hitting Detroit? General Motors, Ford, and FiatChrysler all yesterday lowered guidance. Are you suggesting their full year outlook says they revealed lower than expected second quarter earnings, all of which were impacted by the rising cost of steel and aluminum.

So Mr. Secretary, will the president's negotiations with the E.U. reverse what's going on with the automakers? We are already seeing that they're expecting this to impact their business.

ROSS: Well, I have said before, the impact of steel and aluminum on the auto industry's cost is really fairly minor. It's about one percent on the cost of the vehicle.

So to the degree that that might be passed along, that's possible. But the offsetting thing is what you're seeing unemployment figures. Record low unemployment, more jobs available than there are people available to fill them for the first time ever.

Record low unemployment for African-Americans, for Hispanics, for women, for young people. I mean, the economy is booming and that's what's really important. The other important thing though is the president has made clear he's not going to abandon the industries that just has helped to revitalized.

BARTIROMO: Right. And what's the next priority then Wilbur? We've been talking a lot about the potential for a deal with Mexico. Is that the priority now as you continue to work with the E.U.?

ROSS: Well we're working on a lot of different fronts all at the same time. And that shows you the speed and the breath of the president's sculpt of these trace issues.

We have to get them fixed in a fairly short period of time. They've gone on too long, unchecked by prior administrations. As to Mexico, the new president very quickly appointed the team that would do the trade negotiations for him has made very clear he wants to get a deal done.

And he did all of this without even waiting for his inauguration. He'll be inaugurated on the first of December and it looks pretty clear that his goal would be to try to get something resolved between the United States and Mexico prior to even his inauguration.

BARTIROMO: So you think you -- is it fair to say then the change in leadership in Mexico also was very positive toward better relations with the U.S.?

ROSS: Well potentially so. It certainly has made us all feel a lot better than we did during some of the campaign rhetoric.

BARTIROMO: And you think that Canada will be close behind once you do do a deal -- a new NAFTA deal with Mexico?

ROSS: Well we hope so but the immediate focus is much more on Mexico. The issues there are more complex and we think we can get very good progress very quickly.

BARTIROMO: Understood. Let me move on to China Secretary, the president there said this morning that there would be no winner in a global trade war. Your reaction to what's coming out of China?

Do you feel that you've been able to move the needle yet in terms of their theft of intellectual property and technology?

ROSS: Well we haven't seen any formal steps to resolve those issues. But you see these repeated announcements coming out of China, things that they're doing with the banking system bolstering capital, bolstering liquidity.

Clearly, they're feeling a pressure from the tariffs that the president has put on and equally clearly they're having some difficulty implementing their retaliatory tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Do you feel better now that there's this agreement in place with the E.U. potentially teaming up with the E.U. against China to pressure China to stop bad behavior?

ROSS: Well as we know, the E.U. has suggested several times publicly that they hope they could resolve things with us so that they could join with us very aggressively in dealings with China.

We'll have to see what turns out from that but it certainly is a good step regardless what happens with China to move toward a level playing field and zero tariffs, zero nontariff barrier and zero subsidy environment with the E.U.

BARTIROMO: Understood. A lot of great information Secretary, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

ROSS: Thanks Maria.

BARTIROMO: Secretary Wilbur Ross joining us there. Coming up, breaking overnight, an explosion outside the U.S. Embassy in China. We will have the very latest on this Beijing blast.

Then big oil, big profits. Analysts predicting another huge earning season, we're taking a closer look at big oil as they start reporting today.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A bomb exploding near the U.S. Embassy in Beijing overnight, Cheryl Casone with the details now and headlines. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. We're trying to get more details Maria but here's what we know so far, police say the blast injured the 26-year-old man, he was holding the device.

It was made out of fireworks. Authorities say that the suspect is from Mongolia. The motive though, we don't know at this point. The U.S. Embassy was not damaged and thankfully no U.S. personnel or anyone in the area were hurt by this blast.

Well, Qualcomm now planning to scrap its plan to buy NXP semiconductors after the deadline passed at midnight without any word on Chinese regulatory approval. China was the last of nine markets, they needed to approve the $44 billion deal.

This appears to be the latest victim of U.S.-China trade tensions. Shares of Qualcomm, well, they're saving some money I guess, think of it that way. The stock is up a little more than five percent in the premarket right now.

All right. Some other companies we want to talk about, Royal Dutch Shell reporting its second quarter earnings jumping about 30 percent. Net income rise in the $6.02 billion from $1.54 billion from a year earlier. He oil company is obviously benefiting from higher energy prices. Shell now plans to buy back about $25 billion of its stock over the next two years.

They made that announcement. Shares of Shell, lower in the premarket, down almost two and a half percent. The earnings missed analysts estimates but sell over of a mix back for Shell. A lot of more earnings coming up, Amazon as well today Maria. So a lot of big names.

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely. Amazon after the bell. And Qualcomm also this morning announcing it's going to be buying back $30 billion of stock. Buybacks continuing as well. Cheryl, Thank you.

Coming up, if you're suit up to play, stand for the national anthem. That's the mandate from the owner of the Dallas Cowboys this morning. It is the latest twist in this controversy.

Then this, President Trump's star on the Walk of Fame is smashed to pieces again, you won't believe who bailed this guy out of jail after he did that. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Standing for the national anthem, Jared Max now with the latest on the Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones' new requirement. Jared, good morning.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Yes. New and similar to what we've seen Maria. Jerry Jones hasn't really waffled in his public stance on the importance of his players, the men he employs and pays handsomely to stand for the national anthem.

While there is currently no active policy on the anthem as the NFL and Players Association said last week in a joint statement, they are working toward resolution privately. Yesterday Jones spoke out publicly.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JERRY JONES, OWNER, DALLAS COWBOY: Obviously wouldn't dare speak for any of the other owners much less in general about 31 other owners. But as far as the Dallas Cowboys are concerned, you know where I stand.

It's our position that we've always had a written policy in place. Our policy is that you stand at the anthem, tow on the line.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Tow on the line. But what about actions speak louder than words? Remember last season after President Trump had weighed in heavily on the anthem, Jones joined his players and team staff at a momentary kneel before they stood for the anthem. Jerry Jones, where are you today on President Trump?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONES: His interest in what we're doing is problematic from my chair and I would say in general the owner's share. It's unprecedented if you really think about it. Like the very game itself, that's the way it is and we'll deal with it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: And for now there are no new national anthem policies into the NFL, the League and Players Association said last week it will be several weeks before we have a policy in place.

BARTIROMO: Hmm. Your reaction Jack?

BREWER: Well I got two things to say, you know, we talked about this for a long time and I don't think it's going anywhere. You know, the National Football League is the largest wealth creator for young African-American men in this country.

And I just hate to see anything being done that's going to take away from that. I don't want to piss off any fans, I don't want make anyone upset, because I know that those revenues and those resources that are going into communities of color because of these African-American men getting wealth, I want to keep that going.

And so I'll say that first. The second thing I'll say is there are so many issues that are facing NFL players, we talked about this before Jared particularly with concussions and you have all of the drug issues with giving guys too many opioids and all of the crisis that are going on, let's talk about that too Jared.

MAX: Yes. And --

BREWER: I mean --

MAX: -- players, also the retired players --

BREWER: Exactly.

MAX: -- you know, we hear -- you know, we're waiting for a lot of money from NFL settlements. But, again, this anthem issue Maria is tremendous. Jerry Jones, I think speaks the volumes when he says I like everybody would like for this to go away because very much, you know, sports is always the divider where we didn't get politics into sports, that's where we went to get away --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MAX: -- from that. But here we have this intersection where it doesn't necessarily work for everybody.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

BELL: Right. I like what Jack said earlier, if your boss tells you to stand you do it. If my boss tells me to stand giving a presentation, I'm going to do it, you know.

MAX: Yes. Yes. I mean it's --

BREWER: And with football, it's even deeper because we know, we do everything uniform, right? You have -- you wear the same socks, you go to pull them up, you wear the same uniform. You can't wear Adidas, you got to wear Nike.

You know, there's rules. So I'm a big believer in that. You know, I listen to my dad, I listen to my teacher, I listen to law enforcement. I think, you know, that is a reflection of the new society that we have. You know, we've got to start respecting authority again. We got to start listening.

BARTIROMO: But you say the NFL is this great wealth creator, that's because of America.

BREWER: One hundred percent.

BARTIROMO: You know.

BREWER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So it's more than just your boss tells you to stand up, it's because you're honoring America and the flag.

BREWER: That's right.

MCDOWELL: But a lot -- but you'll agree with this and it comes down to the issue of when you go to work, you have to abide by your employer's rules and it's -- and it's different in NFL because there's a player's contract, there's a union contract with the league.

But I can't say whatever I feel like quite frankly, certainly not even in my private life. Is Twitter my private account or is it part of an extension of where I work? I can't say or do whatever I want and not face any consequences.

BARTIROMO: Of course.

MCDOWELL: Even though we firmly believe in the first amendment, the right to free speech and a free press. It -- that is not an unbridled right in this country. And when you're in the workplace, you kind of have -- like you said, there are rules in the NFL and there will be rules about what you can say and do during the national anthem.

BREWER: Right.

MAX: And they're working it out. Hopefully they're going to work it out. Nobody has got here. Roger Goodell isn't, President Trump isn't. This is -- this is working it out, you know, in a sense of just we're going to do it for the first time, we don't have the answers, right? We don't have the answers. The other leagues stand. The other leagues stand. So --

BREWER: That's why (INAUDIBLE) they're not picking on the NFL.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

BREWER: They're not doing anything than any other sports league.

STRIPLING: Yes. You know, I'm certainly glad that hasn't made its way to the MLB like you said. You know, that's obviously been a very controversial thing and something that I'm glad that we haven't had to take much part in. But, you know, as a Cowboys fan, I respect Jerry Jones taking the initiative and wanting guys to stand up for the anthem. Obviously, I understand where guys are coming from when they protest and, you know, like I said, glad that baseball is kind of been able to stay away from it. But, you know, look, look forward to seeing guys stand for the national anthem, obviously, that might be continuing thing moving forward. But we 'll see how it goes.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Ross, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

STRIPLING: Cash. Thank you, guys.

BARTIROMO: Ross Stripling joining us there. Comuing up, Energy Secretary Rick Perry will join me. He'll weigh in on trade, tariffs, energy, business with the E.U., and a lot more. Plus, a new take on smart clothing, how Tommy Hilfiger will reward customers for wearing its merchandise, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 26th. Your top stories right now 8:32 a.m. on the east coast. The Bears taking a swipe at Facebook in the premarket this morning. The social media giant getting hammered, down 20 percent right now, after reporting disappointing sales and revenue guidance, $150 billion in market value wiped out in the extended hours last night after the company's conference call on earnings.

More technology stocks reporting today, Amazon and Intel, reporting this afternoon, Amazon right after the closing bell. That's going to be one to watch today. Down 1-1/3 percent going into those numbers. We are an hour away from the opening bell this morning, and Futures are indicating a mixed start to trading. We're just getting the durable goods number out. The durable goods report just hitting the wire coming in well below analysts' expectations, durable goods up one percent last month, versus an estimate of three percent, not a major reaction, though, from markets, NASDAQ still down 50 points, that's largely on weakness in tech on the heels of Facebook, Dow Industrials up 43 points. Off of the highs but nonetheless showing a gain on the Dow.

In Europe, this morning, we heard from the European Central Bank which left interest rates unchanged. The DAX Index in Germany up 1-1/3 percent, it's been strong all morning on a -- on a deal with the E.U., and the U.S. The CAC Quarante in Paris is up a third of a percent, the FT-100 in London flat. The Asian markets closed mostly in the red overnight with the exception of Korea, that was up three-quarters of one percent.

The end of tariffs troubles on the horizon, president trump detailing his plan with the European Commission President after yesterday's meeting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: This is why we agreed today, first of all, to work together towards zero tariffs, zero nontariff barriers, and zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods. We will also work to reduce barriers and increase trade and services, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, medical products, as well as soybeans. Soybeans is a big deal!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The President calling it a big day for free and fair trade. Meanwhile, Snapchat (INAUDIBLE) investigators are turning to Snapchat and Fitbit to help in a search for a college student missing since July 18th. Authorities are hoping the data can help them pinpoint her location. Big Tommy is watching you, apparently, Tommy Hilfiger, taking their rewards program to the 21st century. The company's new line features smart chip technology in the clothes, gives you points every time you wear their clothes, I guess they're tracking you as well.

Poor Paul, House Speaker Paul Ryan taking a page from Jimmy Kimmel's book reading some mean tweets about himself. And they don't pull any punches. We'll have that for you also, coming up. Right now, though, America charges forward with energy production. The United States looks to secure its place as the world's leading producer of oil and natural gas. The first natural gas liquification facility on the east coast is being dedicated today. It comes less than a day after the President strikes a major energy deal with the European Union.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The European Union wants to import more liquefied natural gas, LNG, from the United States, and they're going to be a very, very big buyer, so they'll be able to diversify their energy supply which they want very much to do, and we have plenty of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now, with an exclusive look at the new facility is Energy Secretary Rick Perry. Mr. Secretary, it's good to see you this morning, thanks so much for joining us.

RICK PERRY, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF ENERGY: You're welcome, Maria. It's a beautiful place out here.

BARTIROMO: And you are leading the dedication of this new plant today. How important is the new plant to this trade deal and easing trade tensions with the E.U.?

PERRY: Well, obviously, this is one of a total of six. We've got two that are up and running right now, four that are in some part of being completed and ready to be selling U.S. LNG across the world. But this is a fabulous opportunity to send a message. I was in Belgium about two weeks ago talking to my counterparts in the E.U., as I'd also talked to some folks from other parts of the world as well. But they know that we have this extraordinary supply. What's happened in the energy secretary is phenomenal, from the standpoint of production or liquefied natural gas, and it has multiple impacts, obviously, for national security in America.

The idea that we're being able to supply our own gas and oil supply but also to go to our allies, and that was the message the President had for the E.U. President yesterday, this isn't just about an economic thing for the United States, it's about the supply and the security of our allies in the European theater. They don't have to sit there and be held hostage with just one supply of gas. The United States where there's going to be going into Poland, where there's going to be coming in to the southern part of the European Union. They can rest assured that the United States is going to be there, be a supplier with no strings attached of liquefied natural gas.

BARTIROMO: So, what kind of a deal are we talking about? I mean, because I know that the President pushed back at the NATO meeting just a couple weeks ago, basically said look, we're protecting you from Russia and you're buying your gas from Russia. So, is this -- is he going to take some of that market share?

PERRY: Well, absolutely. That's what we intend to do. The Nord Stream II and the Turkish Stream which coming in from the south. Neither one of those are commercially viable. They're there so that Russia can be the sole supplier of energy for the European Union. The vast majority of the E.U. understands that, and they're not for those two lines as well. Germany is, I think Austria has a tendencies to be for it as well because they've got a company that is going to help construct it, but the final decision-making process, I think the Europeans recognize fully that the United States is a supplier of LNG, that they want to have, and it does a multitude of things, not only does it give them some security from a national security standpoint, it also will have a massive positive impact upon the environment.

We've seen that right here in the United States with over the last decade, 14 percent decrease in our carbon emissions, and that's what the Europeans are really focused on as well. So, they can two things that are really good for them, national security, and helping their environment, and the United States and our LNG is going to be a major player with that.

BARTIROMO: So, tell us about Dominion Energy Cove Point LNG. This is the second natural gas liquification facility to enter service and the first to be built on the east coast. Tell us the significance of it and what kind of production you're expecting here?

PERRY: Yes, in an international partnership, Japan and India are both our partners in this plan, as you can see right over my shoulder, there's a tanker that's waiting to be filled, and sent on its way. When I was over in India earlier in the year, we had a -- we had a load of gas coming in to India for the first time, so these are amazing times, but the message is clear. The United States is blessed because of innovation, hydraulic fracturing and our ability to directionally drill to have access to the shale gas, an unconventional play. It is putting America in a place that we haven't been in 60 years, a net exporter of natural gas.

So, geopolitically, you think about, Maria, five years ago, where we were from the standpoint of being reliant upon some countries who didn't necessarily have our best interests in mind to today being the largest oil and gas producer in the world. A stunning turnaround and anyone who would argue that that's bad for the United States, and we're going to be able to -- on the environmental side -- I think again, it can't be understated how much of an impact it has to take those old inefficient plants off that are running in China, in India, and in Germany, for that matter, replace it with LNG, and I will suggest that for the Germans and for anyone else, the best interest there is in American LNG not relying upon the Russians as their sole source.

BARTIROMO: The President has talked a lot about the price of oil and about manipulation going on in the market. Do you see more production impacting oil prices as well?

PERRY: Well, here is the real issue from my perspective, the United States can fill the pipelines around the world, as a matter of fact, we fill the pipelines so much in United States that that's our limiting factor. Going out of the Permian Basin into the world market, it is restricted at this particular point in time because we don't have the pipeline capacity. So, building those pipelines, getting the spigot open in a bigger way from my perspective and I think from the President as well, is a clear message that that's the way to help address the price of crude, let's get more in the market, it's just a plain economic standpoint of supply and demand. And when there's a huge demand out there right now, lower restrictions in our pipelines, but over the next 12 to 18 months, we'll be opening them up.

BARTIROMO: I want to get your take on this, Russian hackers reportedly infiltrated a network of electric utilities last year, it's according to The Wall Street Journal, a Department of Homeland Security official said that it could have led to blackouts or even worse, how serious is the risk for hackers to be successful in the near future, Sir?

PERRY: Well, it's obviously a real concern that we have, you know, five years ago, this wasn't something we're particularly worried about, but over -- I mean, literally millions of times a month, you will see companies that are being hit, particularly these electrical control panels. The sector- specific agency that has the responsibility for that is the Department of Energy. So, we're working on it, we stood up a new office called Caesar with cybersecurity as being the real focus there. Tuesday, I'm going to be in New York City with the Secretary of Homeland Security and some other folks who have cybersecurity in their portfolios as well to talk about the United States and our focus upon cybersecurity in this country. It is real, but we've got some of the best in the world that are doing their due diligence at our national labs to come up with the defensive and the offensive ways to deal with this.

BARTIROMO: Then, there's Iran, America is pressuring its allies to stop importing oil from Iran ahead of the reinstated sanctions next week. Iran is threatening unspecified countermeasures. What might they be? Your reaction to Iran.

PERRY: Maria, the President has been very straightforward, he's been very blunt with the Iranians. The destabilization of the Middle East and other places around the world, he's just not going to put up with it. And whatever we need to do to send a message that Iran can be -- you know, they can -- they can be participants in the world order, they can be participants in that part of world and do it in a civil and a peaceful thoughtful way. If they don't, the President has been very clear, there will be powerful sanctions, there will be strong pushback from United States and our allies, sending the message -- this isn't about the Iranian people, this is about the leadership in that country, the revolutionary guard in particular, you know, act decent in the world you live in and you can expect to do business with the United States. If you don't, there will be hell to pay.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, he has been very clear. Secretary, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

PERRY: Good. Maria, so long.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it, Secretary Rick Perry joining us there. Coming up, getting rewarded for wearing clothes, how Tommy Hilfiger is giving customer prices for wearing its brand, coming up. Then Paul Ryan poking some fun at himself, the House Speaker's hilarious response to reading mean tweets about himself, later this hour. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets cheering the thaw in trade tensions between the U.S. and the European Union, following President Trump's discussion with E.U. Commissioner Jean-Claude Juncker. We want to talk more about that in a minute. We're going to welcome Stuart Varney. By the way, yesterday, Stuart said all I want to see is Juncker and President Trump walk out with smiles and be happy, and the markets are going to turn, and that's exactly what happened.

BELL: Sounds like is exactly what happened.

BARTIROMO: Look at the big reaction at the -- after the close.

BELL: There was. I would have like to see --

BARTIROMO: No, even before the close, sorry.

BELL: -- more clarity on the auto tariffs, but you know, this is a great step in the right direction.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, let's bring in Stuart Varney who called it, host of "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, you called it. This time yesterday, you and I posed the question, what happens if we get some good news on trade, does the market pop? I said, yes. I think you said, yes, too, Maria. Come on.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But you -- but you had the idea, and that was a great idea.

VARNEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Because it's true, that's exactly what the market wanted, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, that's right. And now, there may be a little bit of a follow on today. May I remind you that there's a delegation from Mexico in D.C. right now, talking trade, they want to wrap up a trade deal, a bilateral trade deal, you could possibly get some more smiling faces, not necessarily the news conference, but some smiley faces when they walk out of the meeting. That could mean another small leg up for the overall market. But, to me, the most important thing in that trade deal is that they, the Europe (AUDIO GAP) take that China, and they're going to take a lot of our energy, natural gas, take that Russia. Seems to me that the Europeans blinked and Trump won again. That's the way it seems to me.

BARTIROMO: Well, yes. We'll see. I mean, they said that they're going to work towards zero tariffs, but let's not forget the aluminum and steel tariffs are still in place, and they said also, Dagen, that it's non-auto. That's really what the sticking point was, the auto (INAUDIBLE)

VARNEY: Yes, yes.

MCDOWELL: That rally was purely based on the fact that this is a de- escalation of tensions, it is a truce on additional tariffs, particularly the threat of tariffs on the European automobile imports. But, again, we're still watching because these steel and aluminum tariffs -- what?

VARNEY: Well, look, you're not going to have a tit-for-tat escalation with Europe.

BARTIROMO: No, right.

VARNEY: That's not going to happen, they agreed not to do that yesterday. That was the heart of the good news.

MCDOWELL: But as one of our viewers just --

BARTIROMO: And that's when markets rallied -- yes.

MCDOWELL: As one of our viewers just tweeted, it's time for more go than show. It like let's actually get deals done and let's alleviate some of the pain from the steel and aluminum tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's doing it. I mean, Stuart just said the Mexicans are in the White House today and we keep hearing HHS secretary that we speak with, Stuart, that they feel really good about a deal with Mexico over the near-term, and they assume that Canada is going to get in line as well once the Mexico deal is done.

urn:contentItem:5T3W-SS31-F06X-W0XG-00000-00Tech upgrades: Necessity or trophy investments?2018-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisTech upgrades: Necessity or trophy investments?Andy Peters

Big tech investments cut both ways for bank executives - they make for splashy headlines, but can create investor relations headaches.

Banks of all sizes in recent years have been pouring millions of dollars into upgrading both consumer-facing and behind-the-scenes technology. Some of the numbers have been eye-popping: JPMorgan Chase, for example,will invest $1.4 billionthis year on new mobile banking features, blockchain-related upgrades to the back office and more.

But these big capital outlays are rarely well received by the investment community. Consider the recent case of WSFS Financial in Wilmington, Del.

When the $7.1 billion-asset company announced on Aug. 8 its agreement to buy Beneficial Bancorp in Philadelphia, WSFS said it woulduse cost savings from the deal to invest more than $30 million toupgrade the digital consumer banking experience, its data platform, risk management and workflow automation.

The price tag is sizable for WSFS - it is virtually equal to its second-quarter profit of $28.7 million.

The market's reaction? WSFS' stock has fallen 11% to $49.35 per share since the deal announcement - a sharper nosedive than normal for a buyer in an M&A deal.

Investors are very skeptical about promises that big technology investments will pay off, and that is undoubtedly the reason for the extra stock drop-off in this case, said Joe Gladue, an analyst at Merion Capital Group.

"It's unclear whether tech upgrades really do produce cost savings long term," Gladue said. "Are you just going to have to keep spending on tech, since technology is always changing?"

Investors aren't sold that tech investments are worth the huge expense, said Frank Schiraldi, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill.

"What investors have a tough time with is that the benefit is more intangible" than other large investments that banks can make, such as hiring sales teams away from other banks, Schiraldi said.

"It's harder to see a clear earn-back" with technology investments, Schiraldi said. He noted that WSFS has actually been a leader among banks in making cost-effective tech investments.

WSFS made the decision to use savings from the Beneficial deal to invest in technology because "advances and changing customer preferences are rapidly disrupting the traditional banking model," said Jimmy Hernandez, a spokesman for WSFS.

"Bank management, investors and analysts are aligned about the need for technology investments," Hernandez said.

Constant spending to improve technology has become a fundamental cost of doing business, whether the investor community likes it or not, said Brian Johnson, CEO of the $1.3 billion-asset Choice Financial Group in Fargo, N.D.

"Especially in terms of anti-money-laundering compliance, a lot of technology goes into that," Johnson said. "You've got to invest in the back office, but the consumer expects technology upgrades as well."

Many equity analysts remain unconvinced that huge tech investments are worth the costs. But that view is simply the nature of investors who focus on a bank's stock, rather than its long-term performance, said Scott Durant, an analyst at Kroll Bond Rating Agency.

"Equity markets tend to have a shorter-term focus than bank management teams," Durant said. "You can't cut your way to profitability long-term. Technology like interactive teller machines will enhance earnings power long-term."

Since Choice Financial is privately held, Johnson said he doesn't feel the same resistance to making tech investments as the heads of publicly traded banks. But that doesn't mean Choice can spend unlimited amounts on technology. Since the bank's customers are located in a large territory, its branches serve fewer customers than banks that operate in dense, urban markets.

urn:contentItem:5T3S-S7Y1-F06X-W08V-00000-00Tech upgrades: Necessity or trophy investments?2018-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisTech upgrades: Necessity or trophy investments?Andy Peters

Big tech investments cut both ways for bank executives - they make for splashy headlines, but can create investor relations headaches.

Banks of all sizes in recent years have been pouring millions of dollars into upgrading both consumer-facing and behind-the-scenes technology. Some of the numbers have been eye-popping: JPMorgan Chase, for example,will invest $1.4 billionthis year on new mobile banking features, blockchain-related upgrades to the back office and more.

But these big capital outlays are rarely well received by the investment community. Consider the recent case of WSFS Financial in Wilmington, Del.

When the $7.1 billion-asset company announced on Aug. 8 its agreement to buy Beneficial Bancorp in Philadelphia, WSFS said it woulduse cost savings from the deal to invest more than $30 million toupgrade the digital consumer banking experience, its data platform, risk management and workflow automation.

The price tag is sizable for WSFS - it is virtually equal to its second-quarter profit of $28.7 million.

The market's reaction? WSFS' stock has fallen 11% to $49.35 per share since the deal announcement - a sharper nosedive than normal for a buyer in an M&A deal.

Investors are very skeptical about promises that big technology investments will pay off, and that is undoubtedly the reason for the extra stock drop-off in this case, said Joe Gladue, an analyst at Merion Capital Group.

"It's unclear whether tech upgrades really do produce cost savings long term," Gladue said. "Are you just going to have to keep spending on tech, since technology is always changing?"

Investors aren't sold that tech investments are worth the huge expense, said Frank Schiraldi, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill.

"What investors have a tough time with is that the benefit is more intangible" than other large investments that banks can make, such as hiring sales teams away from other banks, Schiraldi said.

"It's harder to see a clear earn-back" with technology investments, Schiraldi said. He noted that WSFS has actually been a leader among banks in making cost-effective tech investments.

WSFS made the decision to use savings from the Beneficial deal to invest in technology because "advances and changing customer preferences are rapidly disrupting the traditional banking model," said Jimmy Hernandez, a spokesman for WSFS.

"Bank management, investors and analysts are aligned about the need for technology investments," Hernandez said.

Constant spending to improve technology has become a fundamental cost of doing business, whether the investor community likes it or not, said Brian Johnson, CEO of the $1.3 billion-asset Choice Financial Group in Fargo, N.D.

"Especially in terms of anti-money-laundering compliance, a lot of technology goes into that," Johnson said. "You've got to invest in the back office, but the consumer expects technology upgrades as well."

Many equity analysts remain unconvinced that huge tech investments are worth the costs. But that view is simply the nature of investors who focus on a bank's stock, rather than its long-term performance, said Scott Durant, an analyst at Kroll Bond Rating Agency.

"Equity markets tend to have a shorter-term focus than bank management teams," Durant said. "You can't cut your way to profitability long-term. Technology like interactive teller machines will enhance earnings power long-term."

Since Choice Financial is privately held, Johnson said he doesn't feel the same resistance to making tech investments as the heads of publicly traded banks. But that doesn't mean Choice can spend unlimited amounts on technology. Since the bank's customers are located in a large territory, its branches serve fewer customers than banks that operate in dense, urban markets.

"We explored the use of video tellers," Johnson said. "But we have so many locations spread out in rural areas, it's difficult to make that pencil out."

Some banks that have been required by regulators to upgrade Bank Secrecy Act compliance systems, such asInvestors Bancorpin Short Hills, N.J., andEast West Bancorpin Los Angeles, have had no choice but to spend on tech investments, Shaw said.

"It wasn't really an option" for those banks, he said.

Often it makes more sense for smaller banks to adopt software that their core processors offer, Shaw said. There's no need for a smaller bank to create its own proprietary system when a prepackaged system would work just as well.

If bankers get frustrated by equity analysts second-guessing their decisions on technology, a debt analyst points out that bond rating agencies tend to take a longer view of costly investments. That might help executives sell an expensive technology outlay to skeptical board members, said Lisa Kwasnowski, an analyst at DBRS.

"Bond investors tend to have more patience, knowing that the investment technology is critical to being competitively positioned in the future," Kwasnowski said.

urn:contentItem:5MCY-G3G1-DYX2-T530-00000-00Tech vision - Profile - Yasaman Hadjibashi2016-12-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:50ZLexisNexisTech vision - Profile - Yasaman Hadjibashi

Not quite two years into her current role, Yasaman Hadjibashi, chief data officer (CDO) at Barclays Africa Group, is shaking things up. She is leading a data transformation initiative for the continent, focusing on "intelligent banking" and hyper-personalised customer experiences. "We are using big data and machine-learning capabilities to solve problems for our clients across different business units, from retail through to corporate and investment banking," she says. Ms Hadjibashi believes that the bank's approach to data is fundamentally different from other financial institutions.

"When I read about data projects in the financial services industry, especially large banks, they refer to traditional data management in payments, governance, compliance and regulatory reporting," she says. "Instead, I decided to start with the customer and identify specific areas that will make a difference to them." She speaks directly with between 10 and 15 customers every two weeks. "Many are surprised that a senior executive, a CDO, would call but I explain that my job is to innovate and drive value for the customer," she says. A personalised approach will be vital to the future of banking, believes Ms Hadjibashi, especially when engaging with the millennial generation, which are tech savvy, well informed and willing to switch banks more often than previous generations. "A millennial wants things right now and for the experience to be right every time, so banks need to tailor real-time banking experiences to the person," she says. "It's about moving from knowing your customer to understanding and actually predicting all your customers' needs proactively - in a split second."

The value of data

Such a powerful vision requires a fundamental mind-set shift in terms of how value is extracted from data analytics, infrastructure and architecture, according to Ms Hadjibashi. Barclays Africa Group has laid the foundations with Hadoop, an open-source commodity data platform that provides low-cost, scalable storage capability for faster analytics than previous enterprise licensed platforms. "It also allows data analytics to be democratised across all departments and in a more sustainable and accessible way for the masses," she adds. The bank is also investing in data scientists, who combine computer science with mathematics/statistics studies. "They have a very specific skill set in our bank, coupling a creative mind-set with deep analytical problem solving and supreme technical skills, but also with an understanding of the outside business world," she says. But the real magic, according to Ms Hadjibashi, comes from teaming up millennial fast-paced product managers with data scientists to blend in-depth knowledge of the next-generation customer with data technical skills. She says: "All the big tech companies have product managers attached to their apps to identify evolving customer needs, develop new features and functionalities, and then test them - a practice that doesn't traditionally exist in a bank's data department. So I brought together big data and product management to redefine next- generation customer experiences. "Our data product managers are called 'data wunderkinds'. They combine deep knowledge across big data, customer experience and design with agile execution experience, resulting in deliveries that take weeks rather than the usual months."

Smart banking

Since her promotion in February 2015, Ms Hadjibashi and her team have launched an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled banking chatbot, as well as Pronto, an open-source unstructured social analytics platform built in house. "We are inviting a wider global community of data thinkers and problem solvers to not only help enhance the platform itself but to crack business-related use cases," she says. Subsidiary Absa Bank became the first bank in Africa to pilot its chatbot in Facebook Messenger, which stimulates smart free-flow conversations through written text. Using natural language processing and machine-learning techniques, the bank aims to increase account activations among newly onboarded millennial customers for selected product segments. It managed to increase from a traditional 68% activation level to 73% in their pilot population, which "validates the power of new personalised authentic experiences via engaging channels that clearly resonate with millennials", says Ms Hadjibashi. The bank is also getting one step ahead of its customer. It uses big data analytics to send personalised predictive SMS alerts to customers who do not have sufficient funds to meet direct debit obligations three days in advance. "Because we know whether a client has a separate savings account or may have prequalified for an overdraft, we can help them avoid unexpected charges on their account, which are a source of annoyance for customers," says Ms Hadjibashi. She reports that about 67% of customers take action after receiving the tailored SMS messages. She envisions a future where financial services are seamlessly integrated into consumers' daily activities. "Through personalised bots, simple authentic experiences and new lean-formed partnerships with other service providers, I envision banks engaging with their customers, addressing their needs and problems, and in fact predicting most of them with high accuracy," she says.

Career history

Yasaman Hadjibashi

2015 Barclays Africa Group, chief data officer

2014 Barclays, director, chief data office (group operations and technology)

2012 Barclays, innovation and customer experience director (group operations and technology

2010 Barclays, global leaders programme

2009 Deutsche Bank, global markets associate
